paragraph1: As usual, I notice a contrast between the nighttime customers, younger and more ethnically diverse, and those of daytime. Whole segments of the clientele are segregated from one another by the hours during which they do their shopping. Early morning is the time for retired couples, unhurried and well organized, with their own shopping bags and their checkbooks, from which they carefully detach a check at the cash register, remembering to record the amount on the stub.In the mid-afternoon, there are many women on their own—middle-aged, or young, with children—who shop with their own grocery carts made of wipe-clean fabric, a sign that they came on foot or by bus, because they don’t know how to drive or don’t own a car.At 5 P.M., the after-work crowd starts pouring in. The pace grows brisker, more jarring. Schoolchildren with mothers. High-school students. Between 8 and 10 P.M., university students and—more rare at other times of day—women in long dresses and head scarves, always accompanied by a man.
paragraph2: Working at the store gives me a fascinating glimpse into how our customer base changes throughout the day, like clockwork. Early mornings bring in retired couples, who take their time examining products and discussing their choices in detail, often spending up to an hour just to select the perfect produce. As we move into mid-afternoon, I notice a shift to middle-aged and young mothers pushing our easy-to-maneuver carts, many of whom arrive on foot since they don't drive. The atmosphere transforms dramatically at 5 P.M. when the after-work rush begins, filling our aisles with tired office workers while mothers shepherd their children through the store and teenagers browse the snack section. The evening hours, particularly between 8 and 10 P.M., bring yet another change as university students stock up on instant meals and energy drinks, sharing the space with women in elegant long dresses and headscarves who shop alongside their male companions.

paragraph1: Doree and Maggie got into the habit of shopping for groceries together, after they’d picked up the papers at the school. Then sometimes they got take-out coffees at Tim Horton’s and took the children to Riverside Park. They sat on a bench while Sasha and Maggie’s boys raced around or hung from the climbing contraptions, and Barbara Ann pumped on the swing and Dimitri played in the sandbox. Or they sat in the mini, if it was cold. They talked mostly about the children, and things they cooked, but somehow Doree found out about how Maggie had trekked around Europe before training as an optometrist and Maggie found out how young Doree had been when she got married. paragraph2: Doree and Maggie's friendship blossomed around their weekly ritual of collecting school papers and grocery shopping, their children in tow as they navigated the aisles together. When weather permitted, they would extend their outings to Riverside Park, where they could observe their little ones from the comfort of a park bench, or during colder days, retreat to the warmth of Maggie's mini van. Their conversations flowed naturally, weaving between practical discussions about meal preparations and their children's latest adventures. As their bond deepened, they began sharing more intimate details of their lives. Maggie painted vivid pictures of her European adventures before settling into her career as an optometrist, while Doree opened up about her early marriage and the initial joy of effortless pregnancies. She even confided in Maggie about Lloyd's growing suspicions regarding her later fertility challenges, their shared moments of vulnerability strengthening their connection beyond mere grocery store companions.

paragraph1: History is unkind to those it abandons and can be equally unkind to those who make it. Ibn Rushd died (of old age, or so we believe) while travelling in Marrakesh barely a year after his rehabilitation, and never saw his fame grow, never saw it spread beyond the borders of his own world and into the infidel world beyond, where his commentaries on Aristotle became the foundations of his mighty forebear’s popularity, the cornerstones of the infidels’ godless philosophy, saecularis, which meant the kind of idea that came only once in a saeculum, an age of the world, or maybe an idea for the ages, and which was the very image and echo of the ideas he had spoken only in dreams. Perhaps, as a godly man, Ibn Rushd would not have been delighted by the place history gave him, for it is a strange fate for a believer to become the inspiration of ideas that have no need of belief, and a stranger fate still for a man’s philosophy to be victorious beyond the frontiers of his own world but vanquished within those borders, because in the world he knew it was the children of his dead adversary, Ghazali, who multiplied and inherited the kingdom, while his own bastard brood spread out, leaving his forbidden name behind them, to populate the earth.
paragraph2: Ibn Rushd's passing in Marrakesh marked the beginning of a complex and somewhat ironic legacy that would stretch far beyond the Islamic world he knew. The philosopher, who had dedicated his life to reconciling Aristotelian thought with Islamic doctrine, could not have foreseen how his careful commentaries would reshape intellectual discourse in medieval Europe. His death came at a time when his works were already falling into obscurity in his homeland, yet they were simultaneously beginning a remarkable journey across cultural boundaries. The Latin translations of his commentaries on Aristotle would go on to profoundly influence Christian scholasticism and European secular thought, despite his own deeply religious convictions. This twist of fate saw his ideas taking root in contexts that might have troubled the devout Muslim scholar, as they became instrumental in developing secular philosophical traditions. Meanwhile, in the Islamic world, the theological views of his intellectual rival, Ghazali, gained ascendancy, effectively overshadowing Ibn Rushd's rationalist approach to religious understanding. The triumph of Ghazali's ideas in Islamic thought created a striking contrast: while Ibn Rushd's influence waned in his own cultural sphere, his intellectual legacy flourished in distant lands among scholars who approached his work with different cultural and religious perspectives, ultimately shaping Western philosophical discourse for centuries to come.

paragraph1: We placed our wine glasses on the stone table and began to dance. We didn’t dance especially well—we kept bumping our knees—but I held Emily close to me, and my senses filled with the texture of her clothes, her hair, her skin. Holding her like this, it occurred to me again how much weight she'd put on. "You're right, Raymond," she said, quietly in my ear. "Charlie's all right. We should sort ourselves out." "Yes. You should." "You're a good friend, Raymond. What would we do without you?" "If I'm a good friend, I'm glad. Because I’m not much good at anything else. In fact, I’m pretty useless, really." I felt a sharp tug on my shoulder. "Don’t say that," she whispered. "Don't talk like that." Then a moment later, she said again"You’re such a good friend, Raymond." This was Sarah Vaughan's 1954 version of "April in Paris," with Clifford Brown on trumpet. So I knew it was a long track, at least eight minutes. I felt pleased about that, because I knew after the song ended, we wouldn’t dance any more, but go in and eat the casserole. And for all I knew, Emily would reconsider what I’d done to her diary, and decide this time it wasn’t such a trivial offence. What did I know? But for another few minutes at least, we were safe, and we kept dancing under the starlit sky.
paragraph2: Dancing with Emily beneath the starlit sky, I hold her close as Sarah Vaughan's enchanting rendition of "April in Paris" fills the air. The gentle sway of our bodies matches the rhythm perfectly, and I'm grateful for this extended version that stretches past eight minutes, postponing any awkward conversations about the diary incident. Her warmth against me feels both comforting and dangerous – a reminder of boundaries I shouldn't cross. When she mentions Charlie and their need to "sort things out," my heart sinks a little, though I try not to let it show. I've always been pretty useless at hiding my feelings, but tonight I'm doing my best to maintain composure. Emily's whispered assurance that I'm a good friend both soothes and stings; it's a reminder of my place in her life, firmly in the friendship zone. The stars above seem to mock my predicament, twinkling indifferently as we move across the outdoor dance floor. I can smell her perfume, feel the soft fabric of her dress beneath my fingers, and hear the subtle catch in her breath when certain memories surface between us. The promise of dinner afterward looms like a lifeline – at least then we'll have something else to focus on besides this delicate dance we're doing, both physically and emotionally.

paragraph1: For two precious days, Tomas found himself released from the crushing weight of compassion that had become his constant companion, experiencing a relief as profound as a miner's deep slumber after an exhausting week in the depths of the earth. His mind, though temporarily unburdened, remained fixated on Tereza, not with longing but with a complex understanding that it wasn't her physical presence he sought to escape, but rather the overwhelming compassion she stirred within him. This brief respite allowed him to taste a fragment of freedom, like a prisoner granted a temporary release from his chains, as he moved through the weekend with unusual lightness in his steps. However, the liberation proved fleeting, and by Monday, he found himself once again crushed beneath a burden of compassion more oppressive than any personal suffering he had ever endured. This emotional weight descended upon him with the same brutal force as the Russian tanks that had once rolled through the streets, serving as a stark reminder that his capacity for empathy, though noble, was also his heaviest cross to bear.
paragraph2: During those two beautiful days of melancholy, his compassion (that curse of emotional telepathy) had taken a holiday. It had slept the sound Sunday sleep of a miner who, after a hard week's work, needs to gather strength for his Monday shift. Instead of the patients he was treating, Tomas saw Tereza. He tried to remind himself. Don't think about her! Don't think about her! He said to himself, I'm sick with compassion. It's good that she's gone and that I'll never see her again, though it's not Tereza I need to be free of—it's that sickness, compassion, which I thought I was immune to until she infected me with it. On Saturday and Sunday, he felt the sweet lightness of being rise up to him out of the depths of the future. On Monday, he was hit by a weight the likes of which he had never known. The tons of steel of the Russian tanks were nothing compared with it. For there is nothing heavier than compassion. Not even one's own pain weighs so heavy as the pain one feels with someone, for someone, a pain intensified by the imagination and prolonged by a hundred echoes.

paragraph: As I lay in bed, my mind wandered to the girl downstairs. Her sudden appearance and my husband's insistence on letting her stay gnawed at me. I tried to rationalize it, but doubt crept in like a cold draft. I imagined them talking late into the night, sharing secrets I wasn't privy to. My stomach clenched as I pictured her hand on his arm, a gesture too familiar for strangers. I pushed the thought away, only for it to return stronger. Sleep eluded me as I cycled through curiosity, jealousy, and shame at my own suspicions. Part of me wanted to go downstairs and confront them, while another part feared what I might find. I told myself I was being irrational, that trust was the foundation of our marriage. Yet as the hours ticked by, that foundation felt increasingly fragile. I realized it wasn't just about the girl, but about the distance that had grown between us, unnoticed until now. As dawn approached, I felt drained and hollow, unsure of what the morning would bring.

paragraph1: Mevlut and Rayiha's train journey took an enchanting turn as they made a brief stop at Afyonkarahisar station, where Mevlut purchased breakfast provisions for their continuing adventure. As the train wound its way along the Aksu river, Mevlut found himself captivated by Rayiha's genuine wonderment at the passing landscape. Her eyes sparkled as she took in the vibrant tapestry of rural life - quaint towns dotted with poplars, farmers on their tractors, traditional horse carts ambling along dusty roads, and children engaged in spirited football matches near steel bridges spanning the rivers. When Rayiha eventually succumbed to sleep, her head gently resting on Mevlut's shoulder, he experienced a profound sense of both joy and duty toward her. The arrival of two gendarmes and an elderly gentleman in their compartment coincided with Mevlut's observations of Turkey's modernization, evident in the proliferation of transmission towers, trucks, and newly constructed bridges. Yet, his contentment was slightly marred by the sight of political slogans defacing factory walls and impoverished neighborhoods, a reminder of the complex social landscape they traversed.
paragraph2: An hour later, when the train stopped at Afyonkarahisar station, Mevlut jumped off the carriage and bought some bread, two triangles of cream cheese, and a pack of biscuits. A boy was selling tea from a tray. They bought some to have with their breakfast while the train made its way alongside the river Aksu. Mevlut was happy to watch Rayiha as she looked out of the carriage window at the towns they passed, the poplars, the tractors, the horse carts, the kids playing football, and the rivers flowing under steel bridges. Everything was interesting; the whole world was new.Between Alayurt and Uluköy stations, Rayiha fell asleep with her head on Mevlut’s shoulder. Mevlut couldn’t deny that this made him happy, nor that it made him feel a sense of responsibility. Two gendarmes and an old man came to sit in their compartment. Mevlut saw transmission towers, trucks on the asphalt roads, and new concrete bridges and read them as signs that the country was growing and developing. He did not like the political slogans he saw scrawled on factory walls and around poor neighborhoods.

paragraph1: I've often pondered why we humans seem hardwired to prioritize our immediate relationships over the pressing global challenges that threaten our collective future. We spend countless hours worrying about friendships, pursuing romantic connections, and nurturing family bonds, while issues like economic inequality and environmental sustainability remain largely unaddressed. It's both fascinating and maddening how our hearts gravitate toward individual connections rather than tackling the complex problems of resource distribution that could benefit millions. Yet, there's something profoundly touching about this seemingly irrational aspect of our nature. The way we cherish personal bonds, invest deeply in love affairs, and maintain lifelong friendships might appear foolish when compared to larger societal needs, but it's precisely this capacity for intimate connection that makes me believe in humanity's worth and hope for its continued existence. Perhaps our predisposition to love and care for those closest to us, despite its apparent shortsightedness, is our most redeeming quality.
paragraph2: Maybe we're just born to love and worry about the people we know, and to go on loving and worrying even when there are more important things we should be doing. And if that means the human species is going to die out, isn't it in a way a nice reason to die out, the nicest reason you can imagine? Because when we should have been reorganising the distribution of the world's resources and transitioning collectively to a sustainable economic model, we were worrying about sex and friendship instead. Because we loved each other too much and found each other too interesting. And I love that about humanity, and in fact it's the very reason I root for us to survive - because we are so stupid about each other.

Perhaps our predisposition to love and care for those closest to us, despite its apparent shortsightedness, is our most redeeming quality.

paragraph: The trees themselves conspired to lead me to this clearing, this figure with night tight around its shoulders like an old wool shawl. As it looked past me, the tallest oaks and sycamores started to melt. I felt myself unraveling. The figure didn't speak, but poked me with the mocking curiosity of a naturalist examining a peculiar insect. The edge of the figure flickered--raising an arm, maybe?--and a wind heaved upward. It hit me with the weight of a seal hefting itself onto the rocks: a salty, purple smell. I turned toward it and saw the mushrooms. They were the same deep violet as the breeze, and despite the dim light, I counted the specks on each velveteen cap. Just a few inches to the right and I could brush a finger along those gills. The mushrooms, I sensed, were the key to understanding this strange ecosystem, but I knew that I was a trespasser here. Among the forest, the figure, and the mushrooms, I was a temporary disruption.

paragraph1: It was a poorly built house in a way, since wind blew in through cracks and gaps all over the place. Pleasant enough in the summer, but, come winter, it was hell. With no money to buy a space heater, my wife and I and the cat would crawl under the futons once the sun set, literally clinging to each other to keep warm. Many a time we’d wake up to find the water in the kitchen faucet frozen solid.Once winter passed, the spring would come. And spring was a lovely season. She and I and the cat would breathe a sigh of relief. In April, the railroads went on strike for a few days, and we were ecstatic. Not a single train came rumbling by all day. We carried the cat down to the railroad tracks and sat there sunning ourselves. It was so quiet it was as if we were sitting at the bottom of a lake. We were young, just married, and the sunshine was free!Even now, when I hear the word “poor,” I remember that thin, triangular sliver of land. And I wonder, Who could be living there now?
paragraph2: Those first years of marriage in that rickety house still flood my mind with bittersweet memories. My wife and I, along with our faithful cat, struggled through each winter in that poorly insulated dwelling, where our financial constraints meant no space heater to ward off the biting cold. We'd create our own warmth by huddling together under layers of futons, our cat nestled between us, while the kitchen faucet regularly froze solid, a testament to our spartan living conditions. But spring, oh spring was our salvation, bringing with it a warmth that melted away our winter hardships. I particularly remember that April during the railroad strike, when the usual clamor of trains fell silent. We seized that rare moment of tranquility to bask in the sunshine on the empty tracks, our cat contentedly purring beside us, young love making everything seem somehow perfect despite our circumstances. Even now, years later, whenever I hear the word "poor," my thoughts drift back to that humble abode, and I find myself wondering about its current inhabitants, hoping they too find moments of joy amidst the challenges, just as we did in our youth.

paragraph: We all knew each other well. It was a tight-knit community. You had to look closely at the subtle changes to understand that people were keeping secrets. Mrs. Thompson, our cheerful librarian, had become nervous and avoidant. Eric, who once competed fiercely in weekend soccer, lingered on the sidelines, nursing mysterious injuries and deftly diverting questions. The postman, Mr. Crane, whose predictable route was ingrained in our collective memory, began taking inexplicably long breaks, sometimes emerging from shadowed alleyways with furtive glances around. Even the normally outspoken and opinionated Mr. Chen from the corner store had grown more subdued, his eyes darting to the door whenever bell chimes announced a new customer. We were as much bonded by what we shared as what we kept from one another. Everyone's actions spoke to a web of interconnected anxieties, revealing hidden layers to our comfortable routines.

paragraph1: Ka firmly believed that men could be divided into two distinct categories when it came to matters of the heart. The first type required intimate knowledge of a woman's daily routines, personal anecdotes, and quirks before love could blossom in their hearts. In contrast, the second type, to which Ka himself belonged, experienced love's overwhelming force with minimal understanding of the woman in question. These men fell deeply and irrevocably in love based on mere glimpses or brief encounters, their hearts captured by an essence rather than detailed familiarity. This mysterious and somewhat irrational approach to love defined Ka's own romantic experiences throughout his life.
paragraph2: There are two kind of men,' said Ka, in a didatic voice. 'The first kind does not fall in love until he's seen how the girls eats a sandwich, how she combs her hair, what sort of nonsense she cares about, why she's angry at her father, and what sort of stories people tell about her. The second type of man -- and I am in this category -- can fall in love with a woman only if he knows next to nothing about her.

Paragraph 2:
There are two kind of men,' said Ka, in a didatic voice. The second type of man -- and I am in this category -- can fall in love with a woman only if he knows next to nothing about her.

paragraph: Anaís Hernández, a Dominican woman in her late twenties, had an effortless elegance that often led people to assume she was Spanish. Her dark hair, hazel eyes, and sharp features seemed to belong to a Madrid native, not a Santo Domingo-born daughter of a humble tailor. Growing up in a vibrant neighborhood in the capital, Anaís had always felt an affinity for the Spanish culture that permeated her island home. She spent hours listening to her abuela's stories of Franco's regime and the Dominican diaspora in Spain. When she met Rafa, a soft-spoken Spaniard working as a chef in London, their shared cultural heritage created an instant bond. Over steaming cups of café con leche, they exchanged stories of their abuelas' cooking and the struggles of their families. Anaís, however, was hesitant to reveal her own struggles – the sacrifices she made to move to London, the loneliness that still lingered, and the cramped studio flat in London Terrace that she called home. The flat, with its worn carpet and faint smell of mildew, was a far cry from the colorful, lively streets of her childhood. Yet, Anaís had grown fond of the eclectic community in London Terrace, where she'd found solace in the rhythms of the African drumming circle that practiced in the courtyard. As Rafa's visits became more frequent, Anaís began to open up about her life, and he listened with a quiet empathy that put her at ease. But even as their connection deepened, Anaís couldn't shake the feeling that she was living two lives – one in London, and another in the memories of her past.

paragraph1: I still remember that night at the party when we kissed in the utility room, though I couldn't shake the feeling that it wasn't the right place for such an intimate moment. After leaving that cramped space, I retreated to my room, where minutes stretched into hours as I waited, desperately hoping to hear your footsteps approaching my door. The anticipation held me hostage, creating an invisible barrier that kept me from leaving, even as hope gradually gave way to disappointment. I sat there, frozen in place, my ears straining to catch any sound that might signal your arrival, while my mind cycled through endless possibilities of what could have been. It's strange how that same paralyzing sensation has returned now, years later, triggered by your phone call. Just like that night, knowing where my car is parked feels like both a blessing and a curse – the knowledge anchors me in place, making it impossible to leave, as if the mere awareness of its location has created another invisible chain binding me to this moment, to these feelings, to you.

You know I went up to my room and waited for you, right? I mean for hours. And at first I really thought you would come. It was probably the most wretched I ever felt in my life, this kind of ecstatic wretchedness that in a way I was practically enjoying. Because even if you did come upstairs, what then? The house was full of people, it’s not like anything was going to happen. But every time I thought of going back down again I would imagine hearing you on the stairs, and I couldn’t leave, I mean I physically couldn’t. Anyway, how I felt then, knowing that you were close by and feeling completely paralysed by it, this phone call is very similar. If I told you where my car is right now, I don’t think I’d be able to leave, I think I would have to stay here just in case you

paragraph1: There will be a moment of truth at the end of the voyage, when Bob will not appear to pay his bill and pick up his passport; nor will he pack his bags. There will be a flurry of concern, followed by a staff meeting—behind closed doors, so as not to alarm the passengers. Ultimately, there will be a news itemBob, tragically, must have fallen off the ship on the last night of the voyage while leaning over to get a better camera angle on the northern lights. No other explanation is possible.Meanwhile, the passengers will have scattered to the winds, Verna among them. If, that is, she pulls it off. Will she or won’t she? She ought to care more about that—she ought to find it an exciting challenge—but right now she just feels tired and somewhat empty.Though at peace, though safe. Calm of mind all passion spent, as her third husband used to say so annoyingly after his Viagra sessions. Those Victorians always coupled sex with death. Who was that poet anyway? Keats? Tennyson? Her memory isn’t what it was. But the details will come back to her later.
paragraph2: The peculiar circumstances surrounding Bob's disappearance cast a shadow over the final days of the voyage, with his unpaid bill and abandoned passport raising quiet alarms among the ship's personnel. During their discreet staff meeting, carefully orchestrated to maintain calm among the passengers, theories circulated about his last known whereabouts while photographing the northern lights. The timing and location of his vanishing sparked whispers of both tragic accident and something more sinister. Meanwhile, Verna sat alone in her cabin, her mind drifting between satisfaction and exhaustion as she contemplated the success of her carefully constructed plan. The emptiness she felt wasn't entirely unwelcome; rather, it brought an unexpected sense of peace she hadn't experienced since before her marriages. As she gazed out at the dark waters, fragments of Victorian poetry floated through her consciousness, remnants of her third husband's irritating habit of spontaneous recitation. Try as she might, she couldn't place which poet he had so frequently quoted, though the memory of his pretentious literary displays still made her grimace. The ship's gentle swaying seemed to mock the gravity of Bob's absence, as if holding secrets beneath its steady rhythm.

paragraph1: But the airplane is a wonderful thing. You are still in one place when you arrive at the other. The airplane is faster than the heart. You arrive quickly and you leave quickly. You don't grieve too much. And there is something else about the airplane. You can go back many times to the same place. And something strange happens if you go back often enough. You stop grieving for the past. You see that the past is something in your mind alone, that it doesn't exist in real life. You trample on the past, you crush it. In the beginning it is like trampling on a garden. In the end you are just walking on ground. That is the way we have to learn to live now. The past is here." He touched his heart. "It isn't there." And he pointed at the dusty road.
paragraph2: The profound metaphorical significance of airplanes emerges as a powerful tool for navigating emotional landscapes and confronting past experiences. As metal vessels slice through clouds at remarkable speeds, they compress not only physical distance but also the psychological space between present reality and lingering memories. She observes how this swift traversal of space fundamentally alters one's relationship with past grievances, watching as he touches his heart before gesturing toward a dusty road below. The juxtaposition becomes clear - what exists in memory often bears little resemblance to current reality. Through repeated visits, these once-powerful emotional anchors gradually lose their hold, transforming from vivid, haunting presences into abstract concepts that exist solely within the mind's confines. The airplane serves as both literal vessel and symbolic gateway, enabling travelers to physically return to spaces where memories dwell, only to discover that time has rendered these emotional landmarks into something entirely different, something less commanding of their present selves.

paragraph1: Standing under the dim streetlight after our poetry performance, I watched as Melissa adjusted her camera settings, the professional equipment looking almost ceremonial in her practiced hands. She'd caught Bobbi and me just as we were leaving the venue, cigarette smoke curling around us while we discussed her photography, which we'd admired online before. Her movements were deliberate and artistic, matching the sophisticated demeanor I'd noticed during her earlier interactions inside. The conversation flowed easily between drags of shared cigarettes, and when the bar finally shut its doors at midnight, Melissa's invitation to continue our evening at her place felt both surprising and somehow inevitable. We piled into a taxi bound for Monkstown, the three of us settling into a comfortable silence punctuated by occasional laughter. During the ride, I found myself rehearsing witty remarks in my head, determined to present my most engaging self in this impromptu late-night gathering. There was something thrilling about following a near-stranger home, something that made me feel both reckless and alive. I kept stealing glances at Melissa's profile in the passing streetlights, wondering what her house would reveal about her, while Bobbi chatted animatedly from the backseat, seemingly unfazed by the spontaneity of our adventure.
paragraph2: Bobbi and I first met Melissa at a poetry night in town, where we were performing together. Melissa took our photograph outside, with Bobbi smoking and me self-consciously holding my left wrist in my right hand, as if I was afraid the wrist was going to get away from me. Melissa used a big professional camera and kept lots of different lenses in a special camera pouch. She chatted and smoked while taking the pictures. She talked about our performance and we talked about her work, which we’d come across on the Internet. Around midnight the bar closed. It was starting to rain then, and Melissa told us we were welcome to come back to her house for a drink. We all got into the back of a taxi together and started fixing up our seat belts. Bobbi sat in the middle, with her head turned to speak to Melissa, so I could see the back of her neck and her little spoon-like ear. Melissa gave the driver an address in Monkstown and I turned to look out the window. A voice came on the radio to say the wordseighties . . . pop . . . classics. Then a jingle played. I felt excited, ready for the challenge of visiting a stranger’s home, already preparing compliments and certain facial expressions to make myself seem charming.

paragraph1: I watched her diminish in the doorway, her yellow dress a bright spot against the darkening threshold, her smile fixed and brave. The guilt gnawed at me as the distance grew between us, and I felt like a coward for leaving this way. My mind drifted to those evenings when I would return from the cinema, mentally rehearsing answers to her inevitable questions, preparing myself for her searching gaze. Now, as the train pulled away, I could picture her alone in the house, methodically removing traces of my existence – perhaps folding away clothes I'd left behind or rearranging furniture to fill the spaces I once occupied. Through the window, I observed the Sernam buildings sliding past, then the railway workers' houses growing smaller and smaller, each vanishing sight a reminder of what I was leaving behind, of what I was choosing to forget.
paragraph2: After kissing me at the door, she tried to keep talking. Last image of herin the doorway, rounded arms framing her heavy silhouette in a yellow dress—her prettiest one, tight around the chest and the belly—a wide, fixed smile. This time, once again, I felt that I was leaving badly, in a cowardly way.I took the shortest route to the train, the one that goes past the Shell station. There, in the old days, I’d stop to prepare myself for her interrogating look when I returned from the cinema, bracing myself, wiping off what was left of my lipstick. What will people think of you?On the train, I couldn’t help imagining her, washing the dishes in a solitary silence, all sign of my presence soon erased. I watched C. disappear—the Sernam buildings, the railway workers’ housing beside the tracks.

paragraph: Olga couldn't help but feel a mix of frustration and empathy when trying to communicate with Sasha. She was rolling a Sisyphean boulder. The more she worked at it, the further she felt from her goal. Sasha barely responded to her, in cryptic fragments, like she was hiding herself. But Olga suspected it wasn't just Sasha's doing. Andrei, her roommate, seemed to exert some kind of influence over her, whispering in her ear, poisoning her mind. Olga had caught glimpses of their interactions, the way Andrei would nod sympathetically, his eyes glinting with an unspoken understanding. They spoke in their own coded language. She would always be on the outside. At times, Olga wondered if Sasha was even aware of Andrei's manipulation, or if she was simply too afraid to resist. The uncertainty ate at her. Was she trying to help Sasha, or was she just trying to prove a point to herself? It was impossible to know sometimes, what you did for others, and what you did for yourself. She wouldn't give up though. She had to keep trying.

paragraph1: I packed a few things and called Paul. When he pulled up to the corner where I was waiting, I got into his car. By sunset Portland was long gone. In Montana we checked into a motel to sleep. I held myself in bed, rocking with a headache, a sickness in my gut. Paul brought me water and chocolate and watched television. I sat in the car as we drove across the country, and I felt my real life present but unattainable, as if heroin had taken me entirely from myself. Paul and I fought and cried and shook the car with our fighting. We were monstrous in our cruelty. We talked kindly afterward, shocked at ourselves and each other. We decided that we would get divorced. I hated him and I loved him. He had known my mother. I felt trapped, branded, held, and beloved. Like a daughter. “I didn’t ask you to come to Portland,” I screamed. “You came for your own reasons,” I said.
paragraph2: Driving east from Portland with Paul, I watched the landscape blur past our windows as we made our way to Montana, my head throbbing with a familiar ache that reminded me of darker days. The sickness crept through my body, not entirely unlike the heroin that once coursed through my veins, making everything feel distant and unreal. Our relationship had always been a complicated dance of extremes, and this journey was no different. The tension between us built like a pressure cooker until it finally exploded in a violent outburst of screaming and accusations inside the confined space of our car. Later, as we sat in a roadside diner discussing divorce with surprising calmness, I felt the paradoxical pull of both hatred and love for him. Paul's connection to my mother had always added another layer of complexity to our relationship, making me feel simultaneously trapped and treasured. I couldn't shake the feeling that he held me in a grip that was both protective and suffocating, much like the Montana sky that stretched endlessly above us.

paragraph: The incident began inconspicuously, with a small group of robed figures entering the student center just before closing. Within minutes, the intruders brandished weapons and screams echoed through the building. Campus police responded swiftly but were overwhelmed. When it was over, three students lay dead and dozens were injured. In the days that followed, a stunned silence fell over the university. Classes were canceled as investigators combed the scene. Candlelight vigils were held nightly. The culprits were members of a radical online cult, as well as former model students at the university. Their manifesto, found later, revealed a tangled ideology of academic elitism and apocalyptic fervor. As the community grappled with grief and fear, difficult questions arose about free speech, mental health resources, and the university's responsibility to monitor fringe groups. Some students transferred out, unable to feel safe. Others formed support groups and pushed for reforms. The incident not only traumatized the campus but exposed some of its inherent juxtapositions, a bargain between freedom and safety that failed to achieve either.

paragraph1: Standing in the sterile hospital room, I struggled to process the nurse's earlier phone call informing me of my mother's passing shortly after breakfast at the Pontoise care facility. The timing seemed almost mundane, yet it marked the end of a life that had meant everything to me. Now, as I gazed at her still form, the white gauze carefully wrapped around her head and the crisp sheet pulled up to her shoulders, I felt an overwhelming need to ensure everything was perfect for her final journey. The nightdress she had specifically chosen for this moment waited to be placed on her, a final act of dignity and respect for her wishes. I remembered the crucifix in her bedside drawer, knowing it needed some attention before it could rest properly on her chest, as she would have wanted. The nurse's gentle suggestion to visit the administration office for the inventory of her belongings served as a harsh reminder of how few material possessions she had accumulated in her final days. Each item would need to be carefully documented, though their practical value was minimal compared to the weight of memories they carried. The institutional efficiency of death's aftermath felt at odds with the profound personal loss I was experiencing, as I stood there, trying to fulfill my final duties as a child to their parent.
paragraph2: Mother died on Monday 7 April in the old people’s home attached to the hospital at Pontoise, where I had installed her two years previously. The nurse said over the phone“Your mother passed away this morning, after breakfast.” It was around ten o’clock.For the first time the door of her room was closed. The body had already been washed and a strip of gauze had been wrapped around her head and under her chin, pushing all the skin up around her eyes and mouth. A sheet covered her body up to her shoulders, hiding her hands. She looked like a small mummy. The cot sides had been taken down and left on either side of the bed. I wanted to slip her into the white nightdress with a crochet border that she had once bought for her own funeral. The nurse told me one of the staff would see to this and would also take the crucifix my mother kept in her bedside drawer and place it on her chest. The two screws that pinned the copper arms on to the cross were missing. The nurse wasn’t sure they could be replaced. It didn’t matter, I wanted her to have her crucix all the same. On the trolley stood the bunch of forsythia I had brought the day before. The nurse suggested I go straight to the administration office while they drew up an inventory of my mother’s personal belongings. She had very few things of her own left – a suit, a pair of blue summer shoes, an electric shaver.

paragraph: Harper sat alone in the dimly lit apartment, the weight of unpaid bills and unanswered job applications pressing down on her shoulders. Both her mind and her apartment were impossibly cluttered. She stared blankly at the flickering screen of her outdated laptop, the cursor blinking on a rejection email she’d read too many times already. Just as she was about to close it and accept another sleepless night of worry, a soft chime announced a new message. She almost didn't open it. But something, some stubborn hope made her click. The email subject read: "We’d like to discuss your application." The email was from a publishing house she'd always admired. She felt dizzy. It was an invitation for an interview. For a moment, the mess in her apartment didn't matter, and neither did the one in her mind. Harper felt a strange tear, surprised by the enormity of this small relief. She made a small smile at her dim computer.

paragraph1: When Jo first arrived to help with my father's house, I couldn't shake my professional cynicism. Her modern country style, two children from different fathers, and constant talk about coming from "good stock" set off alarm bells in my mind. Years of working with criminals had taught me to be wary of those who overemphasized their desire for self-improvement and respectability. I watched her carefully, half-expecting to discover missing valuables or signs of deceit. But as weeks turned into months, and months into years, Jo systematically dismantled every preconception I had formed. She proved to be not only reliable but remarkably well-educated, handling her duties with an efficiency that impressed even my skeptical father. Her good manners weren't a facade but a genuine reflection of her character. The decent income she earned was well-deserved, and she managed her responsibilities while raising her children with admirable dedication. Looking back, I'm ashamed of my initial judgment. Jo became more than just help; she became an essential part of our household, teaching me a valuable lesson about the dangers of prejudice and the importance of giving people a chance to prove themselves.
paragraph2: Life in these circumstances becomes, in a small way, a constant gamble and an anxiety. We all learn to live with it. And, in fact, after much coming and going we at last found someone suitable for my father’s house. Jo was a country girl, but very much up to the minute, single, with a couple of children, dually fathered, if that is grammatically possible, who brought her quite a tidy sum every week. She spoke of people being of “good stock,” and she seemed to suggest that after her early mistakes she was striving for higher things.This didn’t impress me. I took it as a mark of criminality. I have known criminals all my professional life, and in my experience this is how criminals like to present themselves. But I was wrong about this woman. She stayed, and was good and reliable. She was in her thirties, educated, able to write reasonably well, an elegant dresser (buying stylish things cheap from mail-order firms), and her manners were good. She stayed for six, seven, eight years. She became a fixture. I began—almost—to take her for granted.

Paragraph 1:

I watched her carefully, half-expecting to discover missing valuables or signs of deceit. But as weeks turned into months, and months into years, Jo systematically dismantled every preconception I had formed. She proved to be not only reliable but remarkably well-educated, handling her duties with an efficiency that impressed even my skeptical father. Her good manners weren't a facade but a genuine reflection of her character. The decent income she earned was well-deserved, and she managed her responsibilities while raising her children with admirable dedication. Looking back, I'm ashamed of my initial judgment. Jo became more than just help; she became an essential part of our household, teaching me a valuable lesson about the dangers of prejudice and the importance of giving people a chance to prove themselves.

Paragraph 2:
Life in these circumstances becomes, in a small way, a constant gamble and an anxiety. We all learn to live with it. And, in fact, after much coming and going we at last found someone suitable for my father’s house. Jo was a country girl, but very much up to the minute, single, with a couple of children, dually fathered, if that is grammatically possible, who brought her quite a tidy sum every week. She spoke of people being of “good stock,” and she seemed to suggest that after her early mistakes she was striving for higher things.This didn’t impress me. I took it as a mark of criminality. I have known criminals all my professional life, and in my experience this is how criminals like to present themselves. But I was wrong about this woman. She stayed, and was good and reliable. She was in her thirties, educated, able to write reasonably well, an elegant dresser (buying stylish things cheap from mail-order firms), and her manners were good. She stayed for six, seven, eight years. She became a fixture. I began—almost—to take her for granted.

paragraph: The sun-soaked deck of the speedboat rocked gently, casting ripples in the turquoise water below. Lisa set the picnic basket between them, trying to still her trembling hands as she unrolled the sandwiches. Mark's eyes were fixed on the horizon, where land was a barely perceptible line. Between bites, an eerie silence thickened, punctuated only by the crackling radio on the dashboard. The DJ's voice broke through: "Suspect at large believed to be connected to multiple victims," and Mark's mouth curled up at the corner, like a needle catching a thread. Lisa's pulse quickened. She remembered how he was always a bit too fascinated by the news of the murders and the investigation. Nothing like that had ever happened in Singer Island. His gaze finally shifted, met hers with an intensity that made the hair on her arms stand. All around, waves clawed at their little boat. Mark reached for her hand. The light sagged, clinging to her face like a plastic bag, and the blue went out of the sky.

paragraph1: Halfway through June of 1965, the term at Torrance House School for Girls is over. Juliet has not been offered a permanent job—the teacher she was replacing has recovered from a bout of depression—and she could now be on her way home. Instead, she is taking what she has described as a little detour. A little detour to see a friend who lives up the coast.About a month ago, she went with another teacher—Juanita, the only person on the staff who is near her age, and her only friend—to see a revival of a movie called “Hiroshima, Mon Amour.” Juanita confessed afterward that she herself, like the woman in the picture, was in love with a married man—the father of one of her students. Then Juliet said that she had found herself in somewhat the same situation but had not allowed things to go on because of the tragic plight of the man’s wife, who was a total invalid, more or less brain-dead. Juanita said she wished that her lover’s wife were brain-dead, but she was not—she was vigorous and powerful and could get Juanita fired.
paragraph2: Juliet pulled away from Torrance House School for Girls on that warm June afternoon in 1965, her temporary teaching position having come to an end as the original instructor had recovered. Rather than heading straight home, she chose to meander up the coast to visit a friend, her mind drifting to her recent conversation with Juanita after their viewing of "Hiroshima, Mon Amour." The two teachers, close in age and united in their shared secrets, had formed an unlikely friendship in the halls of Torrance House. That evening, Juanita had confessed her love for a married man - one of her student's fathers - while Juliet admitted to a similar forbidden attraction, though she had chosen not to pursue it due to the man's wife being gravely ill. The confession had prompted Juanita to express a dark wish, one that made Juliet shiver even now as she drove: if only her lover's wife were similarly incapacitated, instead of being the formidable woman who held the power to end Juanita's career with a single complaint to the school board.

paragraph1: The haunting memory of her mother's cremation became an indelible part of Pampa Kampana's consciousness, forever marked by the distinctive scent of burning flesh that permeated the air that day. Despite the traditional inclusion of sandalwood and aromatic spices in the funeral pyre, meant to mask the underlying odors with their sweet fragrance, these additions served only to create a more complex and disturbing olfactory experience. The combination of perfumed wood, exotic spices, and burning human remains created an unforgettable sensory imprint that would pursue her throughout her life. This traumatic event fundamentally altered her relationship with certain smells and spaces, compelling her to adopt a meatless diet and avoid kitchens where flesh was being cooked. The similarity between cooking meat and the memory of her mother's cremation proved too overwhelming, forcing her to create physical and emotional boundaries that would shield her from these triggering reminders of her loss.
paragraph2: For the rest of her life, Pampa Kampana, who shared a name with the river on whose banks all this happened, would carry the scent of her mother’s burning flesh in her nostrils. The pyre was made of perfumed sandalwood, and an abundance of cloves, garlic, cumin seeds, sticks of cinnamon, and other spices had been added to it as if the burning women were being prepared as a gourmet dish to set before the sultan’s victorious generals, but those fragrances—the turmeric, the big cardamoms, and the little cardamoms, too—failed to mask the unique, cannibal pungency of women being cooked alive, and made the odor, if anything, even harder to bear. Pampa Kampana never ate meat again, and could not bring herself to remain in any kitchen in which it was being prepared. All meat dishes exuded the memory of her mother, and when other people ate dead animals she had to avert her gaze.

Despite the traditional inclusion of sandalwood and aromatic spices in the funeral pyre, meant to mask the underlying odors with their sweet fragrance, these additions served only to create a more complex and disturbing olfactory experience. The combination of perfumed wood, exotic spices, and burning human remains created an unforgettable sensory imprint that would pursue her throughout her life. This traumatic event fundamentally altered her relationship with certain smells and spaces, compelling her to adopt a meatless diet and avoid kitchens where flesh was being cooked. The similarity between cooking meat and the memory of her mother's cremation proved too overwhelming, forcing her to create physical and emotional boundaries that would shield her from these triggering reminders of her loss.

Paragraph 2:
For the rest of her life, Pampa Kampana, who shared a name with the river on whose banks all this happened, would carry the scent of her mother’s burning flesh in her nostrils. The pyre was made of perfumed sandalwood, and an abundance of cloves, garlic, cumin seeds, sticks of cinnamon, and other spices had been added to it as if the burning women were being prepared as a gourmet dish to set before the sultan’s victorious generals, but those fragrances—the turmeric, the big cardamoms, and the little cardamoms, too—failed to mask the unique, cannibal pungency of women being cooked alive, and made the odor, if anything, even harder to bear. Pampa Kampana never ate meat again, and could not bring herself to remain in any kitchen in which it was being prepared. All meat dishes exuded the memory of her mother, and when other people ate dead animals she had to avert her gaze.

paragraph: It troubles me that decisions about our lives get made without my voice in the room. Sometimes I feel like you don't consider my perspective, that all I'm supposed to do is be there to observe or nod along but not really contribute. It's not even just about the big stuff, like moving cities or switching jobs; it's the day-to-day things, too—what we spend money on, how we allocate our time. I want to feel like we're partners and we make decisions together. Lately, I've been feeling more like an afterthought. Maybe you don't see it, but when you finalize plans by yourself or assume I'm okay with everything, it stings. I need you to talk to me before you decide things. I need for both of our voices to matter. Otherwise, it feels like we're just coexisting rather than building something together.
text_input:
You are given a paragraph of creative writing. You must score it on a scale from 1 to 10, where 1 is the lowest quality and 10 is the highest quality.

Paragraph:
It troubles me that decisions about our lives get made without my voice in the room. It's not even just about the big stuff, like moving cities or switching jobs; it's the day-to-day things, too—what we spend money on, how we allocate our time. I want to feel like we're partners and we make decisions together. Lately, I've been feeling more like an afterthought. Maybe you don't see it, but when you finalize plans by yourself or assume I'm okay with everything, it stings. I need you to talk to me before you decide things. I need for both of our voices to matter. Otherwise, it feels like we're just coexisting rather than building something together.

where `score` is an integer between 1 and 10.

paragraph: After the divorce, Tom felt as if he'd been hollowed out, his insides scraped clean and left to echo. He moved through his days on autopilot, barely tasting his food or noticing the changing seasons. Sleep eluded him, leaving dark circles under his eyes that seemed to deepen by the week. It wasn't until six months later, when his worn-out shoes began to leak, that Tom realized he needed to take action. Standing in the shoe store, he found himself overwhelmed by the choices, something that had never bothered him before. He spent an hour trying on different pairs, carefully considering the feel of each one, the way they supported his arches, the subtle differences in color. As he laced up a comfortable pair of brown leather oxfords, Tom noticed his reflection in the mirror and saw a spark of interest in his own eyes for the first time in months. Walking out of the store with his new shoes, he felt a small sense of accomplishment, a tiny step forward. That night, he cooked a proper meal for himself and, as he savored the flavors, he realized that perhaps he was ready to start rebuilding his life, one careful choice at a time.
text_input:

Paragraph:

paragraph1: After a couple of months, I started to miss days. Sometimes I would fall asleep without remembering to write anything, but then other nights I’d open the book and not know what to write – I wouldn’t be able to think of anything at all. When I did make entries, they were increasingly verbal and abstractsong titles, or quotes from novels, or text messages from friends. By spring I couldn’t keep it up anymore. I started to put the diary away for weeks at a time – it was just a cheap black notebook I got at work – and then eventually I’d take it back out to look at the entries from the previous year. At that point, I found it impossible to imagine ever feeling again as I had apparently once felt about rain or flowers. It wasn’t just that I failed to be delighted by sensory experiences – it was that I didn’t actually seem to have them anymore. I would walk to work or go out for groceries or whatever and by the time I came home again I wouldn’t be able to remember seeing or hearing anything distinctive at all. I suppose I was seeing but not looking – the visual world just came to me flat, like a catalogue of information. I never looked at things anymore, in the way I had before.
paragraph2: My diary sits untouched on the nightstand, its black cover collecting dust as days blur into weeks of silence. I used to write religiously, filling pages with detailed accounts of my daily life, but lately, my entries have become sparse, fragmented echoes of what they once were. When I do manage to write, I find myself resorting to borrowed words - song lyrics that speak what I cannot, random quotes that seem meaningful yet distant, and copied text messages that hold emotions I no longer fully grasp. The simple black notebook, grabbed hastily from the office supply closet months ago, now feels like a stranger. Looking back at earlier entries from last autumn, I struggle to connect with the person who found joy in describing the patter of rain against windows or the subtle perfume of blooming jasmine. These sensations, once so vivid and meaningful, have faded into mere data points in my consciousness. The world around me has transformed into a clinical inventory of facts - temperature readings instead of feeling the warmth of sunlight, decibel measurements rather than experiencing the melody of birdsong. Each day passes like a PowerPoint presentation of events, stripped of the rich sensory tapestry that once made life feel real and immediate. I've become an observer of my own existence, cataloging experiences without truly feeling them.

paragraph1: Nell's fingers trembled slightly as she held the weathered piece of paper, her eyes scanning Tig's familiar handwriting about the mosquito netting they had once installed together in their community service days. The detailed instructions, written with Tig's characteristic thoroughness, specified that the netting should be carefully packed away in a green bag when the bug season ended. A wry smile crossed Nell's face as she recalled how those well-intentioned instructions had likely been ignored, with the netting probably ending up hastily bundled and tied instead of being properly stored as Tig had meticulously planned. The green bag itself had presumably been discarded long ago, just another forgotten detail in the passage of time. With gentle movements, she tucked the note into her bag, treating it as if it were a precious artifact - which, in many ways, it was. This unexpected discovery felt like a message from beyond, a ghostly hello from Tig that bridged the gap between past and present. As she prepared to return to the city, Nell contemplated how the deceased often leave behind such cryptic breadcrumbs - scattered notes, forgotten instructions, and casual reminders that suddenly transform into profound connections to those we've lost. The note would travel with her, a tangible piece of Tig's essence preserved in simple words about mosquito netting.
paragraph2: The day before Nell and Lizzie are due to leave for the city, Nell comes across a note written by Tig, long ago, when the two of them installed mosquito nets over the beds as a communal service. The mosquitoes can be thick as fur on the outsides of the screens, especially in June; they can squeeze through the tiniest cracks. Once inside, they whine. Even if you’ve got repellent on, they can ruin your night."Large mosquito nettingAt the end of the bug season the large netting should be packed in this bag. The wooden frame, once collapsed, is inserted in the inner compartment of the green bag—Thanks."What green bag? she wonders. Probably it got mildew and someone discarded it. In any case, no one had ever followed these instructions of Tig’s; the mosquito netting is merely left in place and tied into a bundle when not in use.She smooths out the piece of paper carefully and stores it away in her bag. It’s a message, left by Tig for her to find. Magical thinking, she knows that perfectly well, but she indulges in it, anyway, because it’s comforting. She’ll take this piece of paper back to the city, but what will she do with it there? What does one ever do with these cryptic messages from the dead?

paragraph1: On that fateful November morning in 1989, I dialed the familiar number of the Soviet embassy in Paris, my fingers trembling slightly as I waited for a response. When the woman's voice informed me that Mr. S had departed for Moscow just the day before, an overwhelming wave of dread washed over me, eerily reminiscent of that devastating call about my mother's death three and a half years ago. The timing seemed cruelly significant, coinciding with the momentous fall of the Berlin Wall and the gradual unraveling of Soviet power across Europe. My mind wandered back to our first meeting during my writers' tour of Moscow, Tbilisi, and Leningrad the previous year, where Mr. S, a Russian diplomat, had entered my life with the force of an unexpected storm. Our subsequent encounters in France had fallen into a pattern of brief, intense meetings, dominated by physical intimacy and unspoken understanding. These rendezvous, though fleeting, had become the axis around which my entire existence revolved. I found myself living from one call to the next, my days measured not by hours but by the intervals between his contacts. The news of his sudden return to Moscow felt like more than just a departure; it was as if the ground beneath my feet had shifted, mirroring the seismic political changes sweeping across Eastern Europe. His absence left a void that seemed to echo the broader upheaval of that transformative period, making my personal loss feel inexplicably connected to the historic collapse of an entire political system.
paragraph2: On 16 Nov, 1989, I phoned the Soviet embassy in Paris and asked to speak to Mr S. The switchboard operator did not reply. After a long silence, a woman’s voice said‘You know, Mr S returned to Moscow yesterday.’ I immediately hung up. I felt as if I’d heard this sentence before, over the phone. The words were not the same but they had the same meaning, the same weight of horror, and were just as impossible to believe. Later, I remembered the announcement of my mother’s death, three and a half years earlier, how the nurse at the hospital had said‘Your mother passed away this morning after breakfast.’The Berlin Wall had fallen several days before. The Soviet regimes established in Europe were toppling one after the other. The man who had just returned to Moscow was a faithful servant of the USSR, a Russian diplomat posted in Paris.I had met him the previous year on a writers’ junket to Moscow, Tbilisi, and Leningrad, a voyage he had been assigned to accompany. We had spent the last night together, in Leningrad. After returning to France, we continued to see each other. The ritual was invariable. He would ring to ask if he could come around to see me in the afternoon or evening, or, more rarely, a day or two later. He would arrive and stay just a few hours, which we spent making love. Then he left, and I would live in wait for his next call.

paragraph1: After kissing me at the door, she tried to keep talking. Last image of herin the doorway, rounded arms framing her heavy silhouette in a yellow dress—her prettiest one, tight around the chest and the belly—a wide, fixed smile. This time, once again, I felt that I was leaving badly, in a cowardly way.I took the shortest route to the train, the one that goes past the Shell station. There, in the old days, I’d stop to prepare myself for her interrogating look when I returned from the cinema, bracing myself, wiping off what was left of my lipstick. What will people think of you?On the train, I couldn’t help imagining her, washing the dishes in a solitary silence, all sign of my presence soon erased. I watched C. disappear—the Sernam buildings, the railway workers’ housing beside the tracks.
paragraph2: I watched her diminish in the doorway, her yellow dress a bright spot against the darkening threshold, her smile fixed and brave. The guilt gnawed at me as the distance grew between us, and I felt like a coward for leaving this way. My mind drifted to those evenings when I would return from the cinema, mentally rehearsing answers to her inevitable questions, preparing myself for her searching gaze. Now, as the train pulled away, I could picture her alone in the house, methodically removing traces of my existence – perhaps folding away clothes I'd left behind or rearranging furniture to fill the spaces I once occupied. Through the window, I observed the Sernam buildings sliding past, then the railway workers' houses growing smaller and smaller, each vanishing sight a reminder of what I was leaving behind, of what I was choosing to forget.

paragraph1: While saying goodnight to Rico and Rocco, the charismatic Tunisian twins who'd just wrapped up their performance and proudly shared their X Factor Spain success story, I found myself strategically positioning myself to block my children's view of their protruding iPhones - a technology we'd agreed to withhold until they turned twelve. The twins' identical features and synchronized movements still lingered in my mind as our families parted ways to our mirror-image hotel rooms for the night. Once the kids had drifted off to sleep, we adults gravitated to our usual evening ritual, gathering on the balcony with our devices glowing in the darkness. Like clockwork, we joined the silent community of other guests, all of us perched on our respective balconies, united in our nightly ritual of checking that particular Twitter feed. Below us, the Lazy River attraction curved through the property, its Facebook-blue illumination casting an ethereal glow across the night landscape. The scene was made even more surreal by the sight of a fully clothed man, assisted by his colleague, determinedly working against the current with a mop, methodically cleaning the river's edges in what seemed like an endless battle against the perpetual flow.
paragraph2: By the time we reach the gates of the hotel all is dark. A pair of identical twins, Rico and Rocco, in their twenties, with oily black curls and skinny white jeans—twin iPhones wedged in their tight pockets—have just finished their act and are packing up their boom box. "We come runner-up "X Factor" Spain,” they say, in answer to our queries. "We are Tunisia for birth but now we are Spain.” We wish them well and good night, and divert our children’s eyes from the obscene bulge of those iPhones, the existence of which we have decided not to reveal to them for many years, or at least until they are twelve. At the elevators, we separate from our friends and their children and ascend to our room, which is the same as their room and everybody’s room, and put the children to bed and sit on the balcony with our laptops and our phones, where we look up his Twitter, as we have every night since January. Here and there, on other balconies, we spot other men and women on other loungers with other devices, engaged in much the same routine. Down below, the Lazy River runs, a neon blue, a crazy blue, a Facebook blue. In it stands a fully clothed man armed with a long mop—he is being held in place by another man, who grips him by the waist, so that the first man may angle his mop and position himself against the strong yet somniferous current and clean whatever scum we have left of ourselves off the sides.

paragraph1: When he speaks French, his words flow with a certain grace, yet I find myself grappling with our linguistic divide, unable to reciprocate in his mother tongue. At first, this barrier frustrated me deeply, making me feel inadequate and disconnected. But gradually, I've come to embrace these imperfect exchanges between us. The halting conversations and occasional misunderstandings serve as constant reminders that what we have isn't some fairy-tale romance where two souls merge seamlessly into one. Instead, our language gap preserves the beautiful mystery between us, keeping alive the truth that no matter how close we become, he remains fundamentally unknowable. His foreignness, apparent in every accented word, has become precious to me – a testament to his distinct identity that I can love but never fully possess.
paragraph2: At first I was discouraged by the obvious limitations of our exchanges. These were emphasized by the fact that, although he spoke fairly good French, I could not express myself in his language. Later I realized that this situation spared me the illusion that we shared a perfect relationship, or even formed a whole. Because his French strayed slightly from standard use and because I occasionally had doubts about the meaning he gave to words, I was able to appreciate the approximate quality of our conversations. From the very beginning, and throughout the whole of our affair, I had the privilege of knowing what we all find out in the end the man we love is a complete stranger.

His foreignness, apparent in every accented word, has become precious to me – a testament to his distinct identity that I can love but never fully possess.

Paragraph 2:
At first I was discouraged by the obvious limitations of our exchanges. These were emphasized by the fact that, although he spoke fairly good French, I could not express myself in his language. Later I realized that this situation spared me the illusion that we shared a perfect relationship, or even formed a whole. Because his French strayed slightly from standard use and because I occasionally had doubts about the meaning he gave to words, I was able to appreciate the approximate quality of our conversations. From the very beginning, and throughout the whole of our affair, I had the privilege of knowing what we all find out in the end the man we love is a complete stranger.

paragraph1: If religion is the opium of the people, tradition is an even more sinister analgesic, simply because it rarely appears sinister. If religion is a tight band, a throbbing vein and a needle, tradition is a far homelier concoctionpoppy seeds ground into tea; a sweet cocoa drink laced with cocaine; the kind of thing your grandmother might have made. To Samad, as to the people of Thailand, tradition was culture, and culture led to roots, and these were good, these were untainted principles. That didn’t mean he could live by them, abide by them or grow in the manner they demanded, but roots were roots and roots were good. You would get nowhere telling him that weeds too have tubers, or that the first sign of loose teeth is something rotten, something degenerate, deep within the gums. Roots were what saved, the ropes one throws out to rescue drowning men, to Save Their Souls. And the further Samad himself floated out to sea, pulled down to the depths by a siren named Poppy Burt-Jones, the more determined he became to create for his boys roots on shore, deep roots that no storm or gale could displace.
paragraph2: Tradition weaves through life like an invisible thread, binding generations and shaping identities with its quiet yet unyielding presence. For Samad, this cultural tapestry represents both comfort and conflict, as he grapples with its demands while steadfastly believing in its fundamental importance. He sees tradition as the bedrock of cultural identity, the very essence that gives meaning to one's existence, even as he struggles to align his own actions with its principles. The metaphor of roots runs deep in his consciousness, extending beyond mere cultural connection to encompass the very essence of stability and salvation. Even in his moments of doubt, when he recognizes the decay within himself, Samad clings to the notion that even weeds possess roots – suggesting that even flawed foundations have value. This belief becomes particularly poignant as he feels the pull of Poppy Burt-Jones, threatening to uproot him from his cultural moorings. In response, his determination to secure strong roots for his sons intensifies, driven by an almost desperate need to ensure they have the cultural anchor he fears losing himself. This preoccupation with tradition and roots reveals both his deep-seated fears and his unwavering faith in the power of cultural heritage to provide stability and direction.

paragraph1: Afterward, at tea in Shiva’s flat, I talked to my elder sister Kamla. We talked about Shiva as a child; we remembered how, shortly after we had moved to our own house, he had once swallowed a plum and had begun seriously to choke. Fortunately, our house was next door to a doctor’s office, and he was in attendance that afternoon. He swiftly attended to the matter. It was a small crisis, but we could still, my sister and I, after all these years, celebrate the little boy’s escape from death, as though it were something final.I said to Kamla, expecting some solace from her, "And now we have nothing." She said, "And now we have nothing." My sorrow lasted for two years. For two years I mentally dated everything, even the purchase of a book, by its distance from Shiva's death.
paragraph2: Sitting in Shiva's flat with a cup of tea, Kamla and I found ourselves revisiting that terrifying day from his childhood. The image of my little brother choking on a plum remains etched in my memory - his face turning blue, his tiny hands flailing in panic. If it hadn't been for that doctor who lived next door, rushing in and performing the Heimlich maneuver, we might have lost him then. The irony of that memory hits me now, how we saved him that day only to lose him years later. "It's strange being here without him," Kamla whispered, her voice heavy with the same emptiness that's been my constant companion. These past two years since his passing have been measured not in months or seasons, but in the distance from that final day - every moment defined by his absence, every memory tinged with the realization that we can no longer create new ones together.

paragraph1: So the girl decided to set out alone on a face-seeking journey. For the time being, she found a face that would fit her, and pasted it on where her own face should be. Without a face of some kind, people she met along the way would find her strange.The girl walked all over the world. Climbed high mountains, crossed deep rivers, walked across vast deserts, managed to make her way through savage jungles. She was sure that if she came across her face she’d recognize it right away. Since this is a very important part of my existence, she told herself. As she travelled, she met many people, and had all kinds of odd experiences. She was nearly trampled by a herd of elephants, was attacked by a huge black spider, was almost kicked by wild horses.A long time passed as she walked everywhere, examining countless faces as she went, yet she never found her own face. What she saw were always the faces of others. She didn’t know what to do. And before she knew it she was no longer a girl but an adult woman. Would she never be able to find her own face again? She fell into despair.
paragraph2: The girl set out alone on her desperate search for her own face, temporarily wearing a borrowed one to blend in with those she met along her winding path. Through treacherous mountains that scraped the sky and across rushing rivers that threatened to sweep her away, she pressed forward with unwavering determination. The borrowed face felt foreign against her skin as she traversed scorching deserts and dense jungles, narrowly escaping death when a herd of elephants almost crushed her beneath their massive feet. A giant spider's venomous attack and the powerful kicks of wild horses tested her resolve, yet she persisted in her quest for identity. "Where could my true face be hiding?" she wondered repeatedly, her internal dialogue punctuating the endless search. As seasons changed and years passed, the girl's body transformed into that of a woman, but her reflection remained a stranger's. She examined countless faces in villages and cities, in mirrors and still waters, hoping to recognize herself in someone else's features. Yet with each passing day, her heart grew heavier with the realization that her own face remained elusive, lost somewhere in the vast expanse of existence, perhaps never to be found.

paragraph1: Tâm, at seventeen, used her nón lá as a hamper for the clean clothes. At the moment it held only two pairs of tiny pants belonging to her little brother. Hung Sang, an unplanned surprise five years earlier, was now the prince of the family. According to their parents, no boy was as handsome, as talented, as lucky. With his arrival the girls’ status declined. They had become afterthoughts, to be married off quickly. Sang should not be burdened with his sisters’ care. When he grew up, he would have enough to do for his own family and his parents.Tâm wiped sweat from her brow. Mai, three years younger, nattered on, but Tâm only half listened. She was about to graduate from the Catholic school two villages away, and she was wondering how she would continue her studies. Where would she find the money to pay for university? What would her parents say when she confessed that was her goal?"I’m sure you know him. Lanh Phuc. He’s handsome. His is the wealthiest family in their village,” Mai said. “Their home has a real roof. And windows. His father makes sampans…" Mai giggled. “I think he likes me, Chị Tâm. I hope Mama and Papa will agree to a match. I can already picture our wedding.
paragraph2: Balancing her nón lá filled with freshly washed clothes, Tâm navigates the familiar path home while contemplating her increasingly uncertain future. As a seventeen-year-old attending Catholic school, she harbors dreams of university education, though these aspirations seem to dim with each passing day under the weight of financial constraints and familial expectations. Her younger sister Mai, walking beside her, bubbles with enthusiasm about Lanh Phuc, a prosperous young man who has caught her eye, weaving elaborate fantasies about their potential wedding celebration. The sisters' lives have shifted dramatically since their brother Hung Sang's birth, as their parents shower him with preferential treatment, proudly dubbing him the family's prince. This favoritism has relegated the girls to secondary status within the household, intensifying the pressure for them to secure advantageous marriages rather than pursue their individual ambitions. Tâm listens half-heartedly to Mai's animated chatter about Lanh Phuc's family wealth, her thoughts drifting to the mounting stack of university brochures hidden beneath her bed. The traditional nón lá on her head, while practical for carrying laundry, serves as a poignant reminder of the cultural expectations that increasingly threaten to overshadow her educational dreams.
