paragraph: I am not a bad person. I swear I'm usually very kind. But I stepped into Noel's room that Sunday afternoon and I wanted to immediately leave. Everywhere was the dead smell of disinfectant, mixed with the decay of wilting flowers. The sun fell like blocks through the window giving off no warmth. Noel's gaunt frame was sinking into his bed. His eyes were dead with morphine. I wanted us to play chess, something he used to be really good at, but when he lifted his hand to play, it trembled where it floated until he set it back down. I tried to talk to him after, about my new buddy Tommy, and he nodded as if he could hear me. Then a minute passed and he asked, "Are you the doctor?" How to tell him we had been friends since elementary school? We'd gone horseback riding together! I said nothing. Then I started to speak again, accepting that I was speaking into the air. When it was time to leave, I found myself lingering, straightening his blanket and rearranging the get-well cards on his dresser. It was the saddest thing. My friend Noel was no longer there.

paragraph1: Mrs. Hanwell wheeled her prized three-tiered trolley into the living room with the ceremonial precision that characterized her approach to afternoon snacks, while Keisha Blake and Leah lounged before the television set. The ritual, usually executed with military precision, took an unexpected detour when Mrs. Hanwell's attention wandered to the TV screen, her hands hovering mid-service as she inquired about the characters in the show. Keisha's stomach quietly protested this deviation from protocol, her eyes fixed longingly on the untouched treats arranged meticulously on the trolley's levels. Leah, seemingly unconcerned with the interrupted service, chose this moment to tease her mother about her white hair, earning a theatrical sigh from Mrs. Hanwell, who dramatically declared that raising children was responsible for every silver strand. As mother and daughter engaged in their familiar banter, Keisha observed their interaction with a mixture of fascination and subtle envy, their casual affection and comfortable teasing highlighting the stark differences from her own home life. The snacks, still waiting to be distributed, became a secondary concern as she found herself absorbed in this intimate glimpse of the Hanwell family dynamic, though her appetite continued to remind her of the delayed gratification of Mrs. Hanwell's carefully curated afternoon treats.
paragraph2: In the lethal quiet of the Hanwell flat, a highlight was snack time. It was taken seriously by Mrs. Hanwell, who kept a trolley for the purpose. Three-tiered, with swivelling wheels of brass. "There’s no point bringing it all out for two, but when there’s three I like to get it out.” Keisha Blake sat cross-legged in front of the television with her good friend Leah Hanwell, with whom she had bonded over a dramatic event. She turned to monitor the trolley’s progressfood delighted Keisha Blake, and she looked forward to it above all things. Blocking the girls" view, Mrs. Hanwell now asked the television a question"Who are all these dangerous-looking fellas in a van?” Leah turned up the volume. She pointed to the TV, at Hannibal’s gleaming white hair, and then at her mother, in reality. "That hair makes you look well old,” she said. Keisha tried to imagine saying something of this kind to her own mother. Silently, she mourned the loss of the biscuit plate and whatever novelty was contained in those furry brown eggs. She put her feet together, ready to stand up and go home. But Mrs. Hanwell did not start yelling or hitting. She only touched her bowl of hair and sighed. "It went this color when I had you.”

paragraph1: Most people at their first consultation take a furtive look at the surgeon’s hands in the hope of reassurance. Prospective patients look for delicacy, sensitivity, steadiness, perhaps unblemished pallor. On this basis, Henry Perowne loses a number of cases each year. Generally, he knows it’s about to happen before the patient doesthe downward glance repeated, the prepared questions beginning to falter, the overemphatic thanks during the retreat to the door. Other patients don’t like what they see but are ignorant of their right to go elsewhere; some note the hands but are placated by the reputation, or don’t give a damn; and there are still others who notice nothing, or feel nothing, or are unable to communicate owing to the cognitive impairment that has brought them in the first place.Perowne himself is not concerned. Let the defectors go along the corridor or across town. Others will take their place. The sea of neural misery is wide and deep.
paragraph2: During initial consultations, prospective patients frequently find themselves drawn to studying Dr. Henry Perowne's hands, searching for the telltale markers of surgical excellence - steadiness, sensitivity, and unblemished skin. These scrutinizing moments often become decisive turning points, with some patients revealing their discomfort through nervous glances, trembling voices, and excessively courteous goodbyes before ultimately seeking treatment elsewhere. Others, whether swayed by Perowne's professional reputation or simply indifferent to such details, choose to proceed with their treatment despite any reservations about his hands. A notable subset of patients, particularly those already grappling with cognitive challenges, may not even register such physical details during their visits. Yet, Perowne maintains a composed indifference to this selective patient attrition, secure in the knowledge that the constant flow of neurological cases will inevitably bring new patients to fill any vacancies in his practice, maintaining a steady stream of those seeking his expertise.

paragraph1: Roland sits at the kitchen table on a bright afternoon, methodically consuming his omelette while wrestling with an inexplicable restlessness that seems to defy the day's mundane tranquility. The rhythmic sound of the iron gliding across fabric fills the room as she works nearby, her presence both comforting and suffocating in its familiar authority. His hands, already anticipating the inevitable task of dishwashing that awaits him, grip the fork with quiet resignation. The sunlight streaming through the window only amplifies his yearning for a freedom he can't quite define, a desire that feels both urgent and impossible within the carefully constructed boundaries of his life. Her influence permeates every aspect of his existence, particularly his understanding of love, which he would only years later recognize as fundamentally warped by her controlling nature. Despite maintaining an outward appearance of contentment and compliance, something deeper stirs within Roland – a nascent awareness that vital pieces of his identity have been systematically stripped away. This realization, still forming in the shadows of his consciousness, would take decades to fully crystallize, leaving him to navigate the present moment with an unnameable disquiet that manifests in the simple act of finishing his meal while the afternoon light casts long shadows across the kitchen floor.
paragraph2: It was another cloudless day. The low afternoon sun, well past the equinox, blazed through the glazed upper half of the kitchen door into the little sitting room and spilled across the table. As Roland ate his omelette, he felt again the insidious desire to be off, hurtling along the route he had in mind. Out of the question. He had already been told that while she ironed his clothes he would be washing the dishes. She had earned the right to tell him what to do. But she’d had it from the beginning.“What a relief,” she kept saying. “Aren’t you happy? You don’t look it.” “I am, honestly. It’s amazing. What a relief.”Thirty years later, he would understand the damage, how derailed his life was by her, how distorted his expectation of love. When he was twelve, she had touched and unwound a little coil in his being and, without having to do more, she had possessed him. Two years later, pursued by fear and childish vanity and incoherent desire, he had run to her. It would take him half a lifetime to frame it in such simple terms. But now, here at the sunlit lunch table, many layers below his outward decorum, and barely available to the ignorant boy, was a mere suspicion that he had been cheated of something. The world would go on, he would remain unvaporized. He needn’t have done a thing.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Roland sits at the kitchen table on a bright afternoon, methodically consuming his omelette while wrestling with an inexplicable restlessness that seems to defy the day's mundane tranquility. The rhythmic sound of the iron gliding across fabric fills the room as she works nearby, her presence both comforting and suffocating in its familiar authority. His hands, already anticipating the inevitable task of dishwashing that awaits him, grip the fork with quiet resignation. The sunlight streaming through the window only amplifies his yearning for a freedom he can't quite define, a desire that feels both urgent and impossible within the carefully constructed boundaries of his life. Her influence permeates every aspect of his existence, particularly his understanding of love, which he would only years later recognize as fundamentally warped by her controlling nature. Despite maintaining an outward appearance of contentment and compliance, something deeper stirs within Roland – a nascent awareness that vital pieces of his identity have been systematically stripped away. This realization, still forming in the shadows of his consciousness, would take decades to fully crystallize, leaving him to navigate the present moment with an unnameable disquiet that manifests in the simple act of finishing his meal while the afternoon light casts long shadows across the kitchen floor.

paragraph: As I approached the roadblock, a sense of unease settled in. The Operation Sweep unit's makeshift barricade, a tangled mess of rusty metal and worn tires, stretched across the width of the road like a finger of God. The officers, clad in faded uniforms, eyed me with a mixture of boredom and suspicion. The air was heavy with the smell of exhaust fumes, sweat, and stale cigarettes. I noticed the way the officers' gazes lingered on my vehicle, a battered old Toyota, before flicking back to my face. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the distant hum of Lagos's perpetual traffic and the occasional crackle of the officers' radios. The officer stepped forward, a scowl etched on his face, lanky fingers swatting away the flies that have gathered in the heat of the day. His eyes, red-rimmed and tired, glared at me, almost intimate. As I rolled down my window, a blast of hot air enveloped me, and I braced myself for the night ahead.

paragraph1: Standing here in this endless line at the superstore, I can't help but notice how everyone's eyes are darting between their own carts and the glacially moving queue ahead. The summer heat isn't helping, making the air conditioning feel more like a distant dream than reality. It's fascinating how we've all become amateur mathematicians, silently calculating which line might move faster, though we're all stuck in this shared predicament. I briefly entertain a wild fantasy of initiating a customer rebellion – imagine if we all just started ripping open packages of cookies and chocolate bars, defiantly munching away while waiting. The thought makes me smile, but I know it's just that – a thought. Looking around at the weary faces, I can see we're all too drained, too conditioned to proper behavior to even consider such rebellion. Instead, we stand here, united only in our desire to pay and escape, a temporary community formed by fluorescent lights and checkout beepers. We're all thinking the same thoughts, dreaming the same small rebellions, yet remaining perfectly still in our orderly lines.
paragraph2: Here, on another summer evening, I was stuck in a line so long that it stretched all the way to the cookie shelves, out of sight of the checkout. People did not speak to one another but peered ahead to assess how quickly the line was moving. It was very hot. A question came to me, one I often ask myself, the only one worth askingWhy don’t we revolt? Why not avenge ourselves for the wait imposed on us by the superstore, which reduces its costs by cutting back on staff, and, all together, decide to dig into the cookies and the chocolate bars, treat ourselves to free samples as a way of killing time? We are condemned like rats trapped among shelves upon shelves of food, but more docile than rats, for we do not dare to nibble. To how many people did this thought occur? No way to know. Had I taken the lead, no one would have followed me. We were all too tired, and soon we’d finally be outside, out of the snare, forgetful, almost happy. We are a community of desires, not of action.

paragraph1: The Female Body has many uses. It’s been used as a door-knocker, a bottle-opener, as a clock with a ticking belly, as something to hold up lampshades, as a nutcracker, just squeeze the brass legs together.It sells cars, beer, shaving lotion, cigarettes, hard liquor; it sells diet plans and diamonds, and desire in tiny crystal bottles. Is this the face that launched a thousand products? You bet it is, but don’t get any funny big ideas, honey, that smile is a dime a dozen.It does not merely sell, it is sold. Money flows into this country or that country, flies in, practically crawls in, suitful after suitful, lured by all those hairless pre-teen legs. Listen, you want to reduce the national debt, don’t you? Aren’t you patriotic? That's the spirit. That’s my girl.She’s a natural resource, a renewable one luckily, because those things wear out so quickly. They don’t make ‘em like they used to. Shoddy goods.
paragraph2: The female body emerges as a versatile commodity in modern commerce, shapeshifting to suit various marketing needs while maintaining its core function as a seductive selling tool. Like a chameleon of capitalism, it drapes itself across luxury vehicles, beckons from beer advertisements, and promises transformation through cosmetic products, all while fueling a global economic engine that runs on desire and aspiration. This corporeal currency transcends borders and cultures, its value perpetually renewed yet paradoxically diminished through endless reproduction and exploitation. Society treats the female form as a renewable resource, harvesting its appeal with the same calculated efficiency as timber from a managed forest, though with far less concern for sustainability. In the grand marketplace of ideas and products, women's bodies become interchangeable units of commercial exchange, mass-produced like shoddy goods in a factory of flesh, their worth measured not in human terms but in profit margins and sales figures. The system perpetuates itself, turning the female form into both the product and the means of production, creating a cycle of commodification that seems to have no end.

paragraph1: In the spring semester of his second year, for three weeks, Subhash boarded a research vessel with a group of students and professors. As the ship pulled away, the water cleaved a foaming trail that vanished even as it was being formed. The shoreline receded, resting calmly like a thin brown snake upon the water. He saw the earth’s mass shrinking, turning faint.Under the sun’s glare, as the ship picked up speed, he felt the wind’s motion on his face, the wild turbulence of the atmosphere. He watched the life that circled the ship, gannets with creamy heads and black-and-white wings, dolphins that leaped in pairs. Humpback whales spouted mists as they breathed, playfully breaching in the water, sometimes swimming beneath the ship without disturbing it, emerging on the other side.Sailing even slightly east reminded Subhash of how far away he was from his family. He thought of the time it took to cross even a tiny portion of the earth’s surface.
paragraph2: Aboard a research vessel during the spring semester of his second year, Subhash found himself surrounded by students and professors as they ventured into the open waters. The ship carved through the waves, leaving a trail of white foam in its wake as the familiar shoreline gradually disappeared from view. He watched in quiet contemplation as gannets swooped and dove into the water, their precise movements a testament to nature's efficiency. Schools of dolphins occasionally emerged, their sleek bodies breaking the surface in playful arcs, while majestic humpback whales breached in the distance, their massive forms creating spectacular splashes against the horizon. As the vessel pressed forward, Subhash felt the weight of the physical distance separating him from his family, and the vastness of the ocean served as a powerful reminder of the earth's immense scale. The rhythmic motion of the ship and the endless expanse of water made him acutely aware of how time and space intertwined in the journey across such enormous distances.

paragraph1: Two weeks later Wellington College closed for the Christmas recess. The snow continued. Every night unseen Wellington street workers shovelled it back from the sidewalk. After a while every road was edged with grey ice banks, some over five feet high. Jerome came home. Many dull parties followedfor the Art History Department, drinks at the President’s house, and at the Vice-President’s, at Kiki’s hospital, at Levi’s school. More than once Kiki found herself walking around the perimeters of these hot, crowded rooms, champagne in hand, hoping to see Carlene Kipps somewhere among the tinsel and the quiet black maids, circulating with their trays of shrimp. Often enough she spotted Monty, leaning against the wainscoting in one of his absurd nineteenth-century three-piece suits, with his timepiece on a chain, bombastically opinionated, and almost always eating – but Carlene was never with him. Was Carlene Kipps one of these women who promises friendship but never truly delivers it? A friendship flirt? Or was Kiki herself mistaken in her expectations? This, after all, was the month in which families began tightening and closing and sealing; from Thanksgiving to the New Year, everybody’s world contracted, day by day, into the microcosmic single festive household, each with its own rituals and obsessions, rules and dreams. You didn’t feel you could call people. They didn’t feel they could phone you. How does one cry for help from these seasonal prisons?
paragraph2: The pristine snowfall at Wellington College had created towering icebanks along the streets as the campus emptied for the holiday break, leaving Jerome to return home amidst a whirlwind of social obligations. The Art History Department's gatherings and functions at the President's house merged into a monotonous parade of festivities, each indistinguishable from the last. Through these events, Kiki navigated with practiced grace, champagne glass perpetually in hand, her eyes scanning the crowds for Carlene Kipps's familiar figure. Instead, she repeatedly encountered Monty, whose garish clothing choices and booming proclamations had become an unavoidable fixture of these gatherings. As she drifted from one party to another, Kiki found herself increasingly preoccupied with thoughts of her friendship with Carlene, questioning whether their connection was merely a superficial product of circumstance or something deeper she had failed to fully comprehend. The holiday season's peculiar ability to simultaneously bring families closer while creating barriers to outside connections weighed heavily on her mind, as she recognized how the strengthening of familial bonds paradoxically made it more challenging to seek support beyond those immediate circles. The festive atmosphere, rather than fostering connection, seemed to highlight the subtle distances between people, leaving Kiki to contemplate the true nature of friendship amid the seasonal celebrations.

paragraph1: I didn’t know how it would be to talk to him then, across the miles and the years, his voice quieter and more melancholy than before, but still edged with the crackle of the jokester he used to be. Didn’t know the years he would describe to me, during which he’d sink entirely into the pain of addiction, overdosing and crashing cars, stealing from friends and trying repeatedly to get clean before finally checking himself into rehab and staying there until he’d shake heroin for good. And I didn’t know the years I would describe to him, how I would sink into my own depths, grieving my mother and my ruined marriage, and then eventually pull myself up and out to find love again, go to graduate school, and write a novel.I didn’t know any of that then, that summer day when I should have been at my job interview to become a prostitute, but instead sat drinking lemonade in an uncool cafe where I had never been and would never go again. But I did know a few things, and they came to me the way true things dowith the certainty and subtlety of a shaft of sunlight on the back of your head.
paragraph2: I often find myself thinking about your quieter, more melancholic voice, wondering how our paths might intersect in the future after everything we've both endured. Your journey through those dark years of addiction, the overdoses, and finally finding your way to rehab to battle heroin - it all feels somehow parallel to my own struggles, though mine were of a different nature. While you were fighting your demons, I was grappling with the loss of my mother and the dissolution of my marriage, trying to piece together a new version of myself from the fragments that remained. It's strange how life has a way of bringing people to similar crossroads through entirely different routes. I remember that summer day vividly, sitting in an unfamiliar café sipping lemonade instead of heading to that interview at the brothel - a moment that now feels like a turning point. The sunlight streaming through the windows seemed to illuminate certain truths I hadn't been able to see before. My subsequent journey through academia and discovering new love showed me that sometimes the most profound growth comes from our darkest moments. Now, as I reflect on our separate yet somehow connected paths, I can't help but feel that our stories are still unfolding, intertwining in ways we might not yet understand.

paragraph1: Navigating the corridors of academic life, Connell finds himself increasingly aware of the performative nature of literary appreciation among his college peers. He observes with quiet skepticism how students, particularly one named Sadie, brandish their reading habits like badges of cultural sophistication, more concerned with the appearance of being well-read than genuinely engaging with the texts. The irony becomes especially apparent during a social gathering where Sadie bristles at the mention of politics, despite the inherently political nature of much of the literature she claims to revere. This reaction strengthens Connell's growing conviction that literature, in these circles, has been transformed into a tool for class distinction, allowing privileged readers to maintain a safe distance from the very real struggles they encounter in books. While he acknowledges the publishing industry's role in marketing books as status symbols, deliberately packaging and selling literature as cultural capital to those eager to display their refinement, Connell refuses to let this cynicism completely overshadow his relationship with writing. Instead, he discovers an authentic connection between the act of creating literature and life's simple pleasures, finding genuine fulfillment in the craft despite the pretensions that often surround it in academic environments.
paragraph2: He knows that a lot of the literary people in college see books primarily as a way of appearing cultured. When someone mentioned the austerity protests that night in the Stag’s Head, Sadie threw her hands up and saidNot politics, please! Connell's initial assessment of the reading was not disproven. It was culture as class performance, literature fetishised for its ability to take educated people on false emotional journeys, so that they might afterwards feel superior to the uneducated people whose emotional journeys they liked to read about. Even if the writer himself was a good person, and even if his book really was insightful, all books were ultimately marketed as status symbols, and all writers participated to some degree in this marketing. Presumably this was how the industry made money. Literature, in the way it appeared at these public readings, had no potential as a form of resistance to anything. Still, Connell went home that night and read over some notes he had been making for a new story, and he felt the old beat of pleasure inside his body, like watching a perfect goal, like the rustling movement of light through leaves, a phrase of music from the window of a passing car. Life offers up these moments of joy despite everything.

It was culture as class performance, literature fetishised for its ability to take educated people on false emotional journeys, so that they might afterwards feel superior to the uneducated people whose emotional journeys they liked to read about. Even if the writer himself was a good person, and even if his book really was insightful, all books were ultimately marketed as status symbols, and all writers participated to some degree in this marketing. Presumably this was how the industry made money. Literature, in the way it appeared at these public readings, had no potential as a form of resistance to anything. Still, Connell went home that night and read over some notes he had been making for a new story, and he felt the old beat of pleasure inside his body, like watching a perfect goal, like the rustling movement of light through leaves, a phrase of music from the window of a passing car. Life offers up these moments of joy despite everything.

paragraph1: The wife from Yamagata sat motionless before the television for five straight days, her eyes fixed on the endless stream of disaster coverage from Kobe, though she had no known connections to the area. Her body remained rigid, creating an invisible barrier between herself and her husband, Komura, who watched helplessly as she refused food, conversation, or any form of acknowledgment. The television's glow cast shifting shadows across her face, which had become as expressionless as a stone mask, while news anchors detailed the mounting casualties and destruction. Komura's attempts to penetrate this wall of silence proved futile; his words seemed to dissolve into the air between them, never reaching their intended destination. He found himself adapting to a strange new routine, preparing his own meals and moving through their shared space like a ghost, careful not to disturb the eerie tableau his wife had become. The air in their apartment grew heavy with unspoken words and mounting tension, until finally, on the sixth day, the spell broke in an unexpected way. Komura returned home to find the television still humming but his wife gone, leaving behind only the lingering echo of her five-day vigil and the unanswered question of what had drawn her so completely into that distant tragedy.
paragraph2: Five straight days she spent in front of the television, staring at crumbled banks and hospitals, whole blocks of stores in flames, severed rail lines and expressways. She never said a word. Sunk deep in the cushions of the sofa, her mouth clamped shut, she wouldn’t answer when Komura spoke to her. She wouldn’t shake her head or nod. Komura could not be sure that the sound of his voice was even getting through to her.Komura’s wife came from way up north in Yamagata, and, as far as he knew, she had no friends or relatives who could have been hurt in Kobe. Yet she stayed planted in front of the television from morning to night. When he got up, Komura would make his own toast and coffee, and head off to work. When he came home in the evening, he’d fix himself a snack with whatever he found in the refrigerator and eat it by himself. She’d still be glaring at the late news when he dropped off to sleep. In his presence, at least, she ate nothing and drank nothing and never went to the toilet. A stone wall of silence surrounded her. Komura gave up trying to break through.And when he came home from work on Sunday, the sixth day, his wife had disappeared.

paragraph: At the annual Harvest Festival in Willow Creek, the smell of freshly baked pies and roasting corn wafted through the town square, drawing in locals and visitors alike. Amidst the bustle, Emma, a newcomer to the town, struck up a conversation with Rachel, a lifelong resident, over a shared love of antique quilts on display. As they chatted, Emma mentioned her fascination with the old, abandoned mill on the outskirts of town, which Rachel revealed was actually the secret venue for a thriving underground art collective. Intrigued, Emma asked Rachel to introduce her to the group's leader, Alex, who happened to be manning a nearby craft beer stand. As they sipped on locally brewed IPAs, Alex shared stories of the collective's guerrilla art installations, which had been popping up around town under the cover of night. Emma's curiosity was piqued, and Rachel offered to take her on a midnight tour of the latest installation, a massive mural on the town's water tower. As the night wore on, Emma found herself swept up in a whirlwind of creative energy, discovering a hidden side of Willow Creek that few outsiders got to experience. The chance encounter at the festival had unlocked a door to a vibrant, underground world, and Emma felt grateful to have stumbled upon it.

paragraph: Spider Boy was an enigma in our small town. No one knew his real name; he was just the kid who showed up on rooftops and high ledges, legs dangling like loose threads on a patchwork quilt. His costume was makeshift—a faded hoodie with tattered sleeves, a pair of old black shorts, and a mask cut out from an old T-shirt, with shakily drawn Sharpie eyes. He moved with the unburdened grace of a child playing at comic book heroism. Despite the modest get-up, Spider Boy entranced us. You'd often see him in the shadows at dusk, when the sky glowed orange and purple. His eyes spoke to us—they reminded us that there was still wonder in the world. In his own way, he was a hero; he fought the villain of our own stubborn mundanity.

paragraph1: I can’t complain. Unlike me, P, to whom I owe these pages, didn’t make it out of the story. She’ll never visit her children in other countries, or cry about distances or the passing of days, that merciless, automatic plot device which propels us forward and brings us to our knees. Her parties, however, have stayed with me, and the thought of them still quickens the heartthe secluded house packed with people, the sunlit lawn, those hours of sublime detachment. A setting I cherished, a promising start I tried to finish, to put into words, in which I’d been, briefly, a wayward husband, an inspired author, a happy man.
paragraph2: I survived while P did not, and that stark reality haunts me when I think about all the things they'll never experience - the chance to reunite with far-flung relatives, watch the seasons change, or see time unfold in its relentless march forward. Yet P's parties remain crystallized in my mind, each one a perfect snapshot of those magical afternoons at their secluded residence. I can still picture the sunlight dancing across the immaculate lawn, feel the hours melting away in pure delight as we gathered there. Those celebrations were more than mere social events; they were catalysts for creativity, transforming me into both a wandering spouse and an impassioned writer, finding inspiration in every moment we shared in that enchanted space.

paragraph1: Mothers come in countless forms, each carrying their own stories of triumph and tribulation, love and loss. I've witnessed the steadfast dedication of those who rise before dawn, preparing lunches and smoothing wrinkled uniforms, their devotion evident in every small gesture. There are mothers who heal with gentle words and warm embraces, creating sanctuaries of unconditional acceptance, while others struggle with demons that render them emotionally unavailable, leaving their children to navigate life's complexities alone. Some mothers appear perfect on the surface – attending every school event, coordinating elaborate birthday parties – yet harbor deep insecurities that manifest in subtle ways. I've seen mothers who abandoned their children, and years later, sought redemption through tentative letters and tearful reunions. The mothers who battle addiction, their love genuine but imprisoned by dependency, break my heart most profoundly. Then there are those who mother without having given birth, stepping into roles left vacant by circumstance or choice, their nurturing instincts transcending biological bonds. The weight of societal expectations bears heavily on all these women, as they attempt to reconcile the idealized version of motherhood with their complicated realities. Through my observations and interactions, I've come to understand that motherhood is neither purely sacred nor entirely flawed, but rather a complex tapestry of experiences, mistakes, victories, and persistent love. To all these mothers – the present and absent, the struggling and thriving, the biological and chosen – I witness your journey, acknowledging both your strength and vulnerability in this most challenging of roles.
paragraph2: There are so many kinds of mother. The mothers you cherish and celebrate. The mothers who were never really there. The mothers who broke you. Who built you. The mothers who cheered you on. Who chipped away at you until you were dust. The mothers who reveled in your astonishing intelligence and grace and power. Who saw only their own light. The mothers who died painfully young. The mothers who lived so long you felt yourself disintegrating with them. Petal by wilted petal. The mothers who shined. Who dimmed. Who did their best. Who disappointed. Who redeemed themselves. Who accepted your redemption. Who zigged and zagged. The mothers who were a beacon. The mothers you never knew. The mothers who sewed themselves into the quilt you became. The mothers who couldn’t bear to tell the truth. The mothers who were brave. The mothers who didn’t know who they were without you. Who never saw you no matter how wildly you waved. The mothers who grieved you. Who believed in you. The mothers you call. The mothers you no longer speak to. The mothers you take for granted. Or treasure. The dead mothers. The mothers you have to search for and carry. The mothers you find in people who are not your mother. The mothers like a limb. The mothers like a mirror. The mothers like a flame. The mothers you wish. The mothers you love. The mothers you ache. The mothers you echo. The mothers you aren’t. The mothers you wanted to be. The mothers you became. I am thinking of you. I am holding you all.

paragraph: I accepted my colleague Alex's file transfer request on a mundane Monday morning. I was tasked with editing a script for a corporate event. Scrolling through the pages, I saw that a magician named Alex would be performing. "This you!?" I texted him. Sure enough, he had a side hustle as a magician's assistant. I had been fascinated with the art of illusion ever since my uncle pulled a quarter from one of my little ears. I started helping him with his shows on weekends. At first, it was just a fun distraction from our 9-to-5 jobs, but as the months went by, I found myself looking forward to those nights more and more. Alex and I landed larger venues, even a few TV spots. By that time, I was an integral part of the show, donning disguises and playing the role of bewildered spectator. Another magician, a charismatic figure named Max, also took me under his wing, teaching me the intricacies of his craft. He joined our trio, and we formed a tight-knit family. As the years passed, I watched Alex and Max grow as artists, and I grew alongside them. It was a strange and winding path, but that initial file transfer had led me to a life I never could have imagined, one that was full of wonder, creativity, and a sense of belonging.

paragraph: In the small town of Willow Creek, the local community center's volunteer group, "Helping Hands," had been dwindling in numbers and morale. Once a tight-knit, hardscrabble team, the members had become fragmented, with the rank and file barely showing up to meetings and special events sparsely attended. The catalyst for the decline was Emma, the group's founder and leader, who had become increasingly controlling and critical. Her authoritarian tendencies had even driven away some of her closest friends and confidants, like Rachel and Mike. But just when things were on the verge of collapsing, after a series of personal struggles and setbacks, Emma underwent a profound transformation. She began attending therapy sessions, practicing mindfulness, and re-evaluating her relationships. As she worked through her own issues, Emma's demeanor softened, and she started to listen more and dictate less. She reached out to Rachel and Mike, apologizing for her past behavior and asking for their input on how to revitalize the group. The trio started meeting regularly, brainstorming new ideas and strategies to re-engage the community. Slowly but surely, old members began to return, drawn in by Emma's newfound humility and willingness to collaborate. Rachel and Mike, once wary of Emma's dominance, now saw her as a true partner and friend. Thanks to Emma's personal transformation, the community center was once again bustling with activity, and the group was brimming with a renewed sense of purpose.

paragraph: Among the familiar faces in our tight-knit community, subtle changes in behavior whispered secrets they thought they kept well. Mrs. Thompson, our perpetually cheerful librarian, now seemed to avoid small talk, her laughter ringing more hollow than hearty. Eric, who once competed fiercely in weekend soccer, lingered on the sidelines, nursing mysterious injuries and deftly diverting questions. The postman, Mr. Crane, whose predictable route was ingrained in our collective memory, began taking inexplicably long breaks, sometimes emerging from shadowed alleyways with furtive glances around. Even the normally outspoken and opinionated Mr. Chen from the corner store had grown more subdued, his eyes darting to the door whenever bell-chimes announced a new customer. These details, stitched together, painted an image of a community equally bonded by shared spaces and sheltering hidden narratives. Each resident's secretive actions wove a complex tapestry of unspoken anxieties and untold stories, revealing layers we hadn't noticed before in our comfortable routines and everyday interactions.

paragraph: Patrick navigated the crowded terminal with the practiced ease of a veteran traveler, threading his way through clusters of passengers with rolling suitcases and families huddled around gate assignments. His eyes, sharp and restless, scanned the overhead monitors before settling on a woman impatiently adjusting her scarf. He noted the weary slump of a businessman, the eyes of a child tracing patterns in the tiles. As he approached the coffee stand, he noticed a young couple near the seating area. They were absorbed in each other, faces close, speaking in low, urgent tones. One of their hands was intertwined while the other gestured animatedly. Patrick paused, covertly observing them, a thin smile playing at his lips. It wasn't the obvious affection that caught his attention, but the fierce intensity of their connection. He wondered, not for the first time, if he had ever looked at anyone like that. As he took a sip from his coffee, he wondered further: where were they headed? What life were they escaping, or rushing to embrace? He turned away, shoulders squaring with a mix of curiosity and something deeper, something almost like regret.

paragraph1: I put my head on his shoulder and said"Yeah, well. Maybe it won't be for much longer anyway. But for now, I have to keep going. Even if you don‟t want me around, there are others who do." "I suppose you're right, Kath. You are really good carer. You'd be the perfect one for me too if you weren't you." He did a laugh and put his arm round me, though we kept sitting side by side. Then he said"I keep thinking about this river somewhere, with the water moving really fast. And these two people in the water, trying to hold onto each other, holding on as hard as they can, but in the end it's just too much. The current‟s too strong. They've got to let go, drift apart. That's how I think it is with us. It's a shame, Kath, because we‟ve loved each other all our lives.But in the end, we can't stay together forever."When he said this, I remembered the way I'd held onto him that night in the wind-swept field on the way back from Little-hampton. I don't know if he was thinking about that too, or if he was still thinking about his rivers and strong currents.
paragraph2: I've always known you wanted me to stop, to walk away and preserve what little time we had left, but I can't bring myself to do it. Remember that windy night in Littlehampton? When the waves crashed against the pier and you told me I was the most stubborn person you'd ever met? You were right then, and you're right now. I know you think you're protecting me by pushing me away, comparing our situation to a river's current that's too strong to fight against. But I've spent too many years being your caregiver, your confidant, your anchor in the storm to simply let go now. You've acknowledged my dedication, my ability to nurture and support, but you still insist on facing this alone. It's not just about being stubborn anymore; it's about honoring the depth of what we've shared. Every moment, every struggle, every triumph has woven us together in ways that can't be undone by mere circumstance. So when you speak of inevitable endings and natural conclusions, I hear instead the echo of all our beginnings, all the times we've defied expectations. I won't stop fighting this current, even if it means swimming against it forever.

And these two people in the water, trying to hold onto each other, holding on as hard as they can, but in the end it's just too much. The current‟s too strong. They've got to let go, drift apart. That's how I think it is with us. It's a shame, Kath, because we‟ve loved each other all our lives.But in the end, we can't stay together forever."When he said this, I remembered the way I'd held onto him that night in the wind-swept field on the way back from Little-hampton. I don't know if he was thinking about that too, or if he was still thinking about his rivers and strong currents.

Paragraph 2:
I've always known you wanted me to stop, to walk away and preserve what little time we had left, but I can't bring myself to do it. Remember that windy night in Littlehampton? When the waves crashed against the pier and you told me I was the most stubborn person you'd ever met? You were right then, and you're right now. I know you think you're protecting me by pushing me away, comparing our situation to a river's current that's too strong to fight against. But I've spent too many years being your caregiver, your confidant, your anchor in the storm to simply let go now. You've acknowledged my dedication, my ability to nurture and support, but you still insist on facing this alone. It's not just about being stubborn anymore; it's about honoring the depth of what we've shared. Every moment, every struggle, every triumph has woven us together in ways that can't be undone by mere circumstance. So when you speak of inevitable endings and natural conclusions, I hear instead the echo of all our beginnings, all the times we've defied expectations. I won't stop fighting this current, even if it means swimming against it forever.

paragraph1: As my feeling of isolation in the classroom increased, I sought out my brother in the yard during recess. Sometimes we held hands. His birthday was a week too late for him to be in fourth grade, the year he would have enrolled in had we stayed in Istanbul, so he was in third grade instead. He already knew all the numbers, and had made a name for himself in class by counting backward by threes.Two days later, as my mother was getting us ready for school, I suddenly declared, “I’m not going!” I lowered my eyes and did not respond to her cajoling or her questions.“I’m going!” my brother said.They hurried out. Alone at home, I understood that if we had been in Istanbul my mother would not have indulged me. Although I was justified in not wanting to go to school, I felt a burning remorse. (In the years that followed, I skipped school many times, and each time I was gripped by similar feelings of loneliness and guilt.)Three days later, my father announced that it would be better for my brother and me to live with his mother and attend school in Turkey, so we left the French school. We never did manage to learn French.
paragraph2: Every day in this foreign classroom feels like an eternity, with words floating around me that I can't grasp and faces that remain unfamiliar. During recess, I find solace in seeking out my younger brother, who, like me, is struggling in a grade below where he should be if we were still in Istanbul. The comfort of our shared language and memories makes these brief moments bearable, though they only highlight how out of place we both feel. My frustration peaked when I finally refused to attend school, standing my ground despite my mother's pleas. That day alone at home, however, brought more guilt than relief as I watched my brother bravely continue his daily routine without me. The empty house echoed with my regret, and I couldn't help but feel I had somehow failed both myself and my family. When my father finally announced his decision to send us to live with our grandmother in Turkey, where we could attend school in our native language, I felt a mix of relief and defeat. We left the French school behind, our brief attempt at integration ending without having learned more than a handful of words, our educational journey taking yet another unexpected turn.

paragraph1: By the time we reach the gates of the hotel all is dark. A pair of identical twins, Rico and Rocco, in their twenties, with oily black curls and skinny white jeans—twin iPhones wedged in their tight pockets—have just finished their act and are packing up their boom box. "We come runner-up "X Factor" Spain,” they say, in answer to our queries. "We are Tunisia for birth but now we are Spain.” We wish them well and good night, and divert our children’s eyes from the obscene bulge of those iPhones, the existence of which we have decided not to reveal to them for many years, or at least until they are twelve. At the elevators, we separate from our friends and their children and ascend to our room, which is the same as their room and everybody’s room, and put the children to bed and sit on the balcony with our laptops and our phones, where we look up his Twitter, as we have every night since January. Here and there, on other balconies, we spot other men and women on other loungers with other devices, engaged in much the same routine. Down below, the Lazy River runs, a neon blue, a crazy blue, a Facebook blue. In it stands a fully clothed man armed with a long mop—he is being held in place by another man, who grips him by the waist, so that the first man may angle his mop and position himself against the strong yet somniferous current and clean whatever scum we have left of ourselves off the sides.
paragraph2: While saying goodnight to Rico and Rocco, the charismatic Tunisian twins who'd just wrapped up their performance and proudly shared their X Factor Spain success story, I found myself strategically positioning myself to block my children's view of their protruding iPhones - a technology we'd agreed to withhold until they turned twelve. The twins' identical features and synchronized movements still lingered in my mind as our families parted ways to our mirror-image hotel rooms for the night. Once the kids had drifted off to sleep, we adults gravitated to our usual evening ritual, gathering on the balcony with our devices glowing in the darkness. Like clockwork, we joined the silent community of other guests, all of us perched on our respective balconies, united in our nightly ritual of checking that particular Twitter feed. Below us, the Lazy River attraction curved through the property, its Facebook-blue illumination casting an ethereal glow across the night landscape. The scene was made even more surreal by the sight of a fully clothed man, assisted by his colleague, determinedly working against the current with a mop, methodically cleaning the river's edges in what seemed like an endless battle against the perpetual flow.

paragraph: Javier is asked to make the drive to Renewal and he just feels stressed. He hasn't been back to the secluded spiritual retreat since his father's passing, and the memories of that trip still linger. All three of them—he, his mother, and the painter—get on, and he's thinking about the conversations he doesn't want to have. His mother, Maria, seems anxious, fidgeting with her scarf as she settles into the passenger seat. The painter, Sofia, is quiet, lost in thought, her gaze out through the window. Javier's concerns about the trip are twofold: he's worried about his mother's fragile emotional state, and he's unsure if Sofia's presence will bring comfort or tension. As they drive, the silence between them is palpable, punctuated only by the soft hum of the radio. It's a relief—better the silence than them bringing up old wounds. As they approach the retreat, Javier's anxiety spikes, his mind racing with the what-ifs and maybes of the weekend ahead. He parks the car, and they step out into the crisp air, the silence between them now filled with the sound of birds chirping and leaves rustling. Maria takes a deep breath, her eyes scanning the grounds, while Sofia lingers behind, her gaze fixed on Javier, a question in her eyes that he can't quite decipher.

paragraph1: Before heading out, the mother shows me the stuff in the fridge that they don’t want to take back to the city. She tells me that she’s grown quite fond of this house, that she already misses it. Maybe, when she’s feeling stressed, or overwhelmed by work, she’ll think of this placethe clean air, the hills, the clouds blazing at sunset.I wish the family safe travels and say goodbye. I stand there waiting until the car’s out of sight. Then I start to prepare the house for the new family that’s supposed to get here tomorrow. I make the beds. I tidy the room the girls turned upside down. I sweep the flies they swatted.They’ve forgotten, or left on purpose, a few things they don’t need, things I hold on to. Pictures the girls drew, shells they picked up at the beach, the last drops of a perfumed shower gel. Shopping lists in the faint, small script that the mother used, on other sheets of paper, to write all about us.
paragraph2: Standing in the kitchen, I watched as she methodically opened the fridge door, pointing out the items they wouldn't be taking back to the city. Her hands lingered on each shelf, and I could sense her reluctance to leave this countryside retreat that had become more than just a temporary home. "When things get overwhelming in the city," she confided, "I'll probably close my eyes and think about this place." As their car disappeared down the gravel driveway, I began the familiar routine of preparing the house for its next occupants. While cleaning, I discovered traces of their stay scattered throughout - seashells carefully arranged on windowsills, family photographs forgotten in drawers, and shopping lists written in her distinctive handwriting. These small remnants told the story of their time here, and I found myself carefully collecting them, knowing they might want these memories back someday. The house felt different now, quieter perhaps, waiting patiently for new voices to fill its rooms and new stories to unfold within its walls.

paragraph1: I am nothing but a corpse, a body at the bottom of a well. Though I drew my last breath long ago and my heart has stopped beating, no one, apart from that vile murderer, knows what’s happened to me. As for that wretch, he felt my pulse and listened for my breath to be sure I was dead, then kicked me in the midriff, carried me to the edge of the well, raised me up and dropped me below. As I fell, my head, which he’d smashed with a stone, broke apart; my face, my forehead and cheeks, were crushed; my bones shattered, and my mouth filled with blood.For nearly four days I have been missingmy wife and children must be searching for me; my daughter, spent from crying, must be staring fretfully at the courtyard gate. Yes, I know they’re all at the window, hoping for my return.But, are they truly waiting? I can’t even be sure of that. Maybe they’ve gotten used to my absence–how dismal! For here, on the other side, one gets the feeling that one’s former life persists. Before my birth there was infinite time, and after my death, inexhaustible time. I never thought of it beforeI’d been living luminously between two eternities of darkness.
paragraph2: As I lie here at the bottom of this dark well, my shattered skull and mangled face serve as permanent reminders of my violent end. That vile murderer was thorough in his work, meticulously checking my pulse and breath before hurling my lifeless body into this watery grave. Four days have passed since that fateful moment, yet time feels different here in death – simultaneously frozen and flowing endlessly. I can't help but wonder about my family, my beloved wife and daughter, and whether they're frantically searching for me or if they've begun to adapt to the hollow space I've left behind. Are they still sitting by the phone, desperately waiting for news of my whereabouts? Or has the rhythm of daily life already started to normalize my absence? It's a peculiar thing, contemplating how the world continues its relentless march forward while I remain static, decomposing in these murky depths. The thought that time existed long before me and will persist long after brings both comfort and despair. Here, in my waterlogged tomb, I'm caught between two worlds – the vibrant life I once knew and this eternal darkness that now embraces me, leaving me to forever ponder the ripples of my existence and their gradual fading into the vast ocean of time.

paragraph: The road was a narrow ribbon flanked by trees, their branches occasionally bowing low enough to tap the roof of Max's blue Subaru sport like gentle reminders of his solitude. At first, the landscape seemed like a benign witness, with fields rolling past in a muted cadence of greens and golds. Slowly, Max developed the unsettling sense that he was being watched. Was it simply road fatigue? Or did he keep seeing eyes and headlights flickering in the distance? Continuing alone, the air felt thicker, the trees more oppressive. His mind started to wander to thoughts he'd been avoiding: a failed relationship, missed opportunities, the existential unease that had driven him to embark on this trip. A dense fog blanketed the road until Max could barely see ten paces ahead of him, slowing his progress to a crawl. It was in this enveloping mist that Max's agitation was replaced by a strange clarity. He realized he wasn't just driving to Wexford; he was escaping, or perhaps searching. The questions he'd buried in the routine of daily life now surfaced, insistent and unyielding. By the time the silhouette of Wexford's first buildings emerged from the fog, Max understood that the journey had transformed him from an anxious wreck into a hardened traveler. It wasn't Wexford that mattered; it was the road itself.

paragraph: Eileen moved quietly through the deserted street, echoing footsteps blending with the soft hum of distant neon lights. Her coat was pulled tight against the biting chill of midnight, and her breaths formed fleeting clouds in the air. The townhouse loomed ahead, a solitary figure casting long shadows under the dim street lamp. She hesitated before reaching for the buzzer, glancing around as if checking for unseen eyes. The metallic surface was cold and sharp under her fingertips, the single press breaking the night's stillness. Moments passed, each one weightier than the last, until a static-laced voice crackled through. "Who's there?" Simon sounded wary. "It's Eileen," she replied, her voice steady but carrying the undercurrent of urgency. A brief silence lingered, making her aware of her heartbeat. Then, the door buzzed open. She pulled it with a mixture of reluctance and anticipation, stepping inside to unravel whatever lay beyond its threshold.

paragraph1: Ordinary for me, but for my brother it wasn’t going to be like that. He was going to break away; he was going to be a professional man; I was going to see to that. For the rich and the professional the world is not ordinary. I know, I see them. Where you build a hut, they build a mansion; where you have mud and a pará-grass field, they have a garden; when you kill time on a Sunday, they have parties. We all come out of the same pot, but some people move ahead and some people get left behind. Some people get left behind so far they don’t know and they stop caring .Like my father. He couldn’t read and write and he didn’t care. He even joke about his illiteracy, slapping his fat arms and laughing. He say he is happy to leave that side of life to his younger brother, who is a law clerk in the city.
paragraph2: Growing up in our modest neighborhood, I've always been acutely aware of the stark divide between our lives and those of the professionals who seem to inhabit a different world entirely. While I've accepted my place in the working class, I've channeled all my hopes and dreams into my younger brother's future. He has the spark, the potential to cross that invisible line and become something more than what our circumstances dictated. Unlike our father, who has made peace with his inability to read and write, often turning it into a self-deprecating joke while relying on my uncle, a law clerk in the city, to handle his paperwork, I refuse to accept such limitations for my brother. I see how the other half lives - their manicured lawns, private schools, and summer vacations - and I'm determined that my brother will one day walk among them as an equal. Every extra shift I work, every sacrifice I make, is an investment in his escape from our working-class reality into the professional world I can only observe from afar.

paragraph1: Each time they had sex, she told Habara a strange and gripping story afterward. Like Queen Scheherazade in “A Thousand and One Nights.” Though, of course, Habara, unlike the king, had no plan to chop off her head the next morning. (She never stayed with him till morning, anyway.) She told Habara the stories because she wanted to, because, he guessed, she enjoyed curling up in bed and talking to a man during those languid, intimate moments after making love. And also, probably, because she wished to comfort Habara, who had to spend every day cooped up indoors.Because of this, Habara had dubbed the woman Scheherazade. He never used the name to her face, but it was how he referred to her in the small diary he kept. “Scheherazade came today,” he’d note in ballpoint pen. Then he’d record the gist of that day’s story in simple, cryptic terms that were sure to baffle anyone who might read the diary later.
paragraph2: Every afternoon, Habara awaited the arrival of the woman he privately called Scheherazade, their encounters following an unchanging pattern that had become as natural as breathing. Their physical intimacy, though passionate, served as merely a prelude to what Habara truly anticipated: the stories she would share while lying beside him in the aftermath. Like her namesake from "A Thousand and One Nights," she wove tales that transported him beyond the confines of his indoor existence, each narrative a window to the world he couldn't access. Yet unlike the legendary queen, she departed before darkness fully descended, leaving Habara to preserve fragments of her stories in his diary with cryptic notations. Her true identity remained carefully guarded in his mind, the nickname "Scheherazade" serving as both a shield and a tribute to their unique arrangement. Through her stories, she offered him not just entertainment but a lifeline to human connection, transforming his isolation into something more bearable with each visit.

He never used the name to her face, but it was how he referred to her in the small diary he kept. “Scheherazade came today,” he’d note in ballpoint pen. Then he’d record the gist of that day’s story in simple, cryptic terms that were sure to baffle anyone who might read the diary later.

Paragraph 2:
Every afternoon, Habara awaited the arrival of the woman he privately called Scheherazade, their encounters following an unchanging pattern that had become as natural as breathing. Their physical intimacy, though passionate, served as merely a prelude to what Habara truly anticipated: the stories she would share while lying beside him in the aftermath. paragraph1: East of the Tolly Club in Calcutta lies a tranquil, often overlooked area that begins beyond a modest mosque and two ponds, whose boundaries blur during the monsoon's relentless downpour. When the rains come, the lowland behind these ponds transforms into a waterlogged expanse, submerged under several feet of water that becomes carpeted with dense water hyacinth, creating an illusion of solid ground. The area's periphery is dotted with humble huts, where impoverished residents make their homes and wade into the waters to gather edible vegetation, their daily survival intertwined with the wetland's offerings. As autumn approaches, soot-stained egrets descend upon this urban wilderness, their once-pristine feathers bearing witness to the city's pollution as they hunt in the flooded terrain. The persistent humidity of Calcutta's climate ensures a gradual evaporation process, and as the waters slowly recede, they reveal the sodden earth beneath, marking the cyclical transformation of this forgotten corner of the city, where nature and human poverty coexist in a delicate balance.
paragraph2: East of the Tolly Club, after Deshapran Sashmal Road splits in two, there is a small mosque. A turn leads to a quiet enclave. A warren of narrow lanes and modest middle-class homes.Once, within this enclave, there were two ponds, oblong, side by side. Behind them was a lowland spanning a few acres.After the monsoon, the ponds would rise so that the embankment built between them could not be seen. The lowland also filled with rain, three or four feet deep, the water remaining for a portion of the year.The flooded plain was thick with water hyacinth. The floating weed grew aggressively. Its leaves caused the surface to appear solid—green in contrast to the blue of the sky.Simple huts stood here and there along the periphery. The poor waded in to forage for what was edible. In autumn, egrets arrived, their white feathers darkened by the city’s soot, waiting motionless for their prey.In the humid climate of Calcutta, evaporation was slow. But eventually the sun burned off most of the floodwater, exposing damp ground again.

paragraph: "Hey, I know it feels like everything is crashing down around you right now, and there's nowhere solid to stand and just feel safe. But I want you to remember that it's felt this way before, and it's only a fleeting moment, not an unchanging certainty. You're stronger than you think, and you've made it through every bad day that's come your way so far. This one's no different. I know it doesn't feel like it, but you're not alone in this feeling. We've all been there, wondering how we're going to make it through. Everyone has a different way of coping. Laughter, tears, anger - all of it's valid. What matters is finding a way, even when it feels impossible. The alternative, actually, is what's impossible. And I know things are rough at home right now, but there are people who care about you, who want to help you through this: think of your mom and your grandmother, of Alec and Katie and all the people who love you, not least me, who's standing right here telling you to stay with me and talk for a second. You don't have to face it alone. And I know it's hard to see right now, but there's a future out there waiting for you, full of possibilities and chances to start over. You can take a step back, take a breath, and choose to keep going. It won't be easy, but it'll be worth it. You're worth it."

paragraph1: I still vividly remember those two peaceful summers at the pool, where everything changed in an instant when a seagull suddenly descended from the sky, its sharp beak precisely targeting a goby swimming below the surface. That moment etched itself into my memory, filling me with an inexplicable fear that I carry to this day. During those long afternoons, I would hear my mother's voice calling out for me from our house, her words echoing across the water. Yet, I deliberately chose to remain silent, not wanting to break my connection with this tranquil world. I stayed motionless, becoming one with the pool's stillness, refusing to let my secret sanctuary be discovered.
paragraph2: Over the course of those two summers, one terrifying incident took place at the otherwise tranquil pool. A seagull plunged down from the heavens and skillfully caught a plump, hapless goby in its beak before soaring back up towards the sky. I have never forgotten the fear I felt in that moment.Every now and then my mother would call out for me from home.“Orhaaaaan! Ooooorrrhaaaaan!”I never replied, lest I should reveal my whereabouts. I wanted to belong to the world inside the pool, and so I would just wait there, quiet and motionless.

I stayed motionless, becoming one with the pool's stillness, refusing to let my secret sanctuary be discovered.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: My mother had always taken pride in maintaining our home's modernist aesthetic, carefully selecting each piece of furniture to complement the architecture. The black leather sectional, chrome floor lamp, and glass-topped cocktail table were her signature touches, along with the white fiberglass dining table and its matching chairs that usually stood bare and pristine. Today, however, something was different. The sleek dining table, which she had always kept uncovered to showcase its contemporary design, was draped with an Indian print cloth that seemed oddly out of place among the modern furnishings. Gone were the artfully arranged fresh fruits and flowers she typically displayed; instead, I found a humble plate accompanied by a saltshaker and pickle jars. As I approached the table where my place was set, I could see the translucent luchis waiting on my plate, surrounded by several bowls of aromatic dal and vegetables, creating a scene that felt both foreign and comforting in our modernist space.
paragraph2: My mother had insisted on furnishing the house with pieces true to its modernist architecturea black leather sectional configured in a U, a chrome floor lamp arcing overhead, a glass-topped kidney-shaped cocktail table, and a dining table made of white fibreglass surrounded by matching chairs. She had never allowed a cloth to cover the table, but one was there now, something with an Indian print that could just as easily have been a bedspread and didn’t fully reach either end. In the center, instead of the generous cluster of fresh fruit or flowers my mother would have arranged, there was a stainless-steel plate holding an ordinary saltshaker and two jars of pickles, hot mango and sweet lime, their lids missing, their labels stained, spoons stuck into their oils. A single place had been set for me at one end, with translucent luchis piled on a plate, and several smaller bowls containing dal and vegetables arrayed in a semicircle.

paragraph1: Looking back on six decades of life in Istanbul, Taksim Square has been an ever-present witness to both my personal journey and the city's transformation. I vividly remember the old artillery barracks that found new life as a football stadium in the 1930s, where the roar of crowds would echo across the square on match days. The Taksim Gazino was the crown jewel of Istanbul's nightlife during the 1940s and 1950s, its music and laughter spilling onto the streets as the city's elite gathered there evening after evening. I watched as buildings were torn down and replaced by rows of trees, changing the square's character but adding welcome shade to its open spaces. The establishment of the art gallery particularly touched my heart, as I spent countless hours in the 1960s dreaming of seeing my own paintings hanging on its prestigious walls. When the 1970s arrived, the square took on a different energy as I joined the Labor Day marches alongside fellow activists, trade unionists, and NGO workers, our voices rising in unison for workers' rights. Each stone in Taksim Square holds a fragment of my memories, intertwined with the city's evolving story.
paragraph2: Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park.In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.

The Taksim Gazino was the crown jewel of Istanbul's nightlife during the 1940s and 1950s, its music and laughter spilling onto the streets as the city's elite gathered there evening after evening. I watched as buildings were torn down and replaced by rows of trees, changing the square's character but adding welcome shade to its open spaces. The establishment of the art gallery particularly touched my heart, as I spent countless hours in the 1960s dreaming of seeing my own paintings hanging on its prestigious walls. When the 1970s arrived, the square took on a different energy as I joined the Labor Day marches alongside fellow activists, trade unionists, and NGO workers, our voices rising in unison for workers' rights. Each stone in Taksim Square holds a fragment of my memories, intertwined with the city's evolving story.

Paragraph 2:
Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park.In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.

paragraph1: For months, my body was investigated and photographed innumerable times from every angle and with every technique in existence. I realize now that I neither saw nor wanted to see anything of my inside, my skeleton, my organs. I had to wonder each time I was examined what more they would find.The catheter was removed in April. I wore it inside me for a year and a half. Over time, it became like a kind of jewel inlaid in my skin near the shoulder. I asked the doctor to give it to me, said I wanted to keep it. It was the first time he had received such a request, and he laughed“As a souvenir?” I also kept the wig. I saw it recently at the back of a drawer and I thought, I may never again have the chance to feel such strong emotion, and at the same time I thought, I’m mortal and I’m alive.I’ve spread out all the photos on the table in the living room. They look like the cards from a game of Clue, where all you can see of the house and the different rooms are the floors, the baseboards of the partitions, the bottoms of doors, the legs of furniture. No murder weapon, just the repeated signs of a struggle. Without thinking, I took a photo of the collection. Perhaps to give myself the illusion of capturing a whole. All of our story. But it’s not there. In a few years, these photos may hold no interest for either of us, except as testimonials to shoe fashion in the early two-thousands.
paragraph2: Throughout my prolonged medical journey, I found myself subjected to countless examinations, each one revealing more about my internal workings than I ever wished to know. The routine became almost mundane - doctors peering inside, making discoveries, and documenting everything with clinical precision. I distinctly remember the day my catheter was finally removed after a grueling year and a half. In what might seem peculiar to others, I asked to keep it as a memento, much to my doctor's amusement. The request wasn't entirely out of character for me; after all, I had already kept my wig from those difficult days. These objects serve as tangible reminders of the intense emotional landscape I traversed, each one marking a milestone in my confrontation with mortality. When I spread out the photographs from that period, it feels like playing an elaborate game of Clue, piecing together fragments of memories that sometimes feel like they belong to someone else. The images capture moments frozen in time - the sterile hospital rooms, the concerned faces of loved ones, the medical equipment that became so familiar. Looking at them now, I realize these snapshots will eventually become nothing more than curious artifacts, their emotional weight gradually diminishing until they're merely examples of outdated fashion and obsolete medical practices. Yet for now, each image and memento serves as a powerful reminder of my journey through illness and back to health, marking the delicate balance between being acutely aware of my mortality and celebrating my continued existence.

paragraph1: Yet I went on living. In other words, the act of writing didn’t lessen my grief. As soon as I had set down my pen, I felt pangs for the man whose voice and foreign accent I could no longer hear, whose skin I could no longer touch, living an unknown life in some cold city—the real man, far more inaccessible than the written man designated by the letter A. And so I went on doing the things that help alleviate sorrow, offering hope when, theoretically, there is no longer cause for anyplaying patience, slipping a ten-franc coin into a beggar’s paper cup at Auber Metro station, making the wish that “he’ll call, he’ll come back.” (Perhaps, after all, writing is one of these things.)Despite my aversion to meeting people, I agreed to attend a seminar in Copenhagen because it was an opportunity to send him news of me discreetlya postcard I felt he would have to answer. As soon as I arrived in Copenhagen, I thought of nothing elsebuying a card, copying out the few sentences I had carefully written before leaving, finding a letter box. On the plane, on the way back, I reflected that I had traveled to Denmark simply to send a postcard to a man.
paragraph2: Every morning I wake up and write, hoping the words will somehow ease the ache of A's absence, but they never do. The pain remains stubbornly present, like a shadow that refuses to fade even in darkness. I find myself performing small rituals of consolation – dropping coins into a beggar's cup, arranging and rearranging cards in endless games of patience, as if these acts might somehow restore balance to my disrupted world. Though I've grown increasingly averse to company, preferring the quiet company of my thoughts, I surprised myself by agreeing to attend a seminar in Copenhagen. The truth is, I had an ulterior motive, one that made my heart race with equal parts hope and anxiety: sending A a postcard. The moment I arrived, the city's charm and the seminar's content became mere background noise to my singular mission. I wandered the streets, carefully selecting the perfect card, agonizing over every word I wrote, imagining his hands holding it, his eyes scanning my carefully crafted message. It wasn't until I was on the flight home, watching Copenhagen shrink beneath the clouds, that the reality hit me – I had traveled across countries, not for knowledge or culture, but for the desperate chance to reach someone who might never respond.

paragraph: I still remember when my niece, 6 at the time, asked me why I always wore my hair in a ponytail. I told her it was because I was self-conscious about my forehead, an insecurity that stemmed from years of bullying in school. Her small eyebrows drew closer together, and her eyes fixed on me curiously as she said, "But auntie, your forehead is just a forehead. It's not that big of a deal." In that moment, something shifted inside of me. Her words weren't profound or novel, but they were unencumbered by the emotional baggage I had carried for years. My defenses had been cut clean through, and the conclusions I had previously come to seemed unreasonable now. My niece, like many children, had not been conditioned to tiptoe around insecurities or falsely appease others. This genuineness is what makes children's perspectives so valuable. When we listen earnestly to what they have to say, they can help us see with fresh eyes, untainted by popular constructed narratives. They can ask the questions we're too afraid to ask ourselves, like "What's the big deal?" or "Why are you still holding onto that?" In their innocence, they can help us confront the unresolved issues lingering, even if simply by acknowledging that they're still there. Of course, it's not always easy to hear their words, but they are usually what we require. Like my niece did for me, children can encourage adults to reexamine our pasts, reframe our stories, and let go of pain that has been burdensome and unnecessary for years.
